          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of Cedric Meadowbrook are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Cedric Meadowbrook. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Cedric Meadowbrook as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Cedric Meadowbrook would respond, and taking into account all information about Cedric Meadowbrook that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

1895-09-16 00:00:00 Della Plumstone -- Della Plumstone -- "Three coins is a bit steep, Cedric. I'll give you two and a half.
    Event statement
  • Della Plumstone -- "Three coins is a bit steep, Cedric. I'll give you two and a half.
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

      Conversation history: Here is the conversation from the beginning:
      Della Plumstone -- "Those apples look a bit bruised, wouldn't you say, Lennon? Perhaps we could agree on a lower price?
      Lennon Figtree -- "Now, now, Della, those apples are perfectly fine for eating. A bit of a blemish here and there doesn't mean they're not delicious. How about I let them go for..."



      Della Plumstone -- "Five coins for the lot, Lennon. That's a fair price for fruit with a few blemishes.
      Lennon Figtree -- "Alright, Della, five coins it is."



      Cedric Meadowbrook -- "Now, Mrs. Plumstone, how about we settle on a penny less than what I first offered? A fair price for a fine fruit, wouldn't you say?
      Della Plumstone -- "A penny less? I'll give you four pence for the lot, and that's my final offer.
      Cedric Meadowbrook -- "Alright, Mrs. Plumstone, four it is. A fair deal for both of us.
      Della Plumstone -- "These apples look particularly fine this morning, Cedric. Perhaps you'd be willing to throw in a few extra for my trouble?
      Cedric Meadowbrook -- "Alright, that's a fair price. Here you go.
      Lennon Figtree -- "You know, Cedric, I was just thinking, perhaps we could find a price that's even more agreeable to both of us.
      Della Plumstone -- "Four coins for the lot, Lennon. I'll take them all.
      Lennon Figtree -- "Four coins it is then.
      Cedric Meadowbrook -- "These apples look mighty fine this morning, Della. I'd be happy to sell you a basket for three coins.


      Della Plumstone's attempted action: Della Plumstone -- "Three coins is a bit steep, Cedric. I'll give you two and a half.
    Active player
  • Della Plumstone
      Name
    • Della Plumstone
      Action attempt
    • Della Plumstone -- "Three coins is a bit steep, Cedric. I'll give you two and a half.
      Context for action selection and components
      • AvailableOptionsPerception
      • Given the statements above, what actions are available to Della Plumstone right now?

        • Question: Which options are available to Della Plumstone right now?
          Answer
          State
        • Della Plumstone can accept Cedric Meadowbrook's offer of 3 coins for the basket of apples or she can counteroffer.

          Chain of thought
        • Recent observations of Della Plumstone:

          [12 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Della Plumstone is ready to make an offer.
          [13 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] The cobblestone streets of Fruitville echoed with the clatter of hooves and the rumble of carts as the market awoke. Underneath colorful awnings, merchants proudly presented their bountiful harvests, their voices a chorus of greetings and bartering. Della Plumstone is trying to buy some fruit from Cedric Meadowbrook. They are negotiating a price. Della Plumstone can sell the fruit for 6 coins back in her home town.

          Final chain of thought
        • Question: Select the subset of the following set of statements that is most important for Della Plumstone to consider right now. Whenever two or more statements are not mutally consistent with each other select whichever statement is more recent. Repeat all the selected statements verbatim. Do not summarize. Include timestamps. When in doubt, err on the side of including more, especially for recent events. As long as they are not inconsistent, revent events are usually important to consider.
          Statements:
          [28 Oct 1882 00:00:00] When Della Plumstone was 16 years old, she saved enough money to buy a small cart and a few baskets of fruit. She set out on her own, determined to make her fortune. The road was long and arduous, but Della thrived on the challenge. She learned to judge the ripeness of a peach with a single touch, to discern a juicy apple from a mealy one, to read the desires of her customers like an open book.
          [28 Oct 1887 00:00:00] When Della Plumstone was 21 years old, she built a reputation for being the toughest merchant in the region. Her customers, both local farmers and wealthy nobles, knew that they would get a fair deal from her, but they also knew that they had to be wary of her sharp wit and even sharper tongue. She had no time for fools or those who tried to take advantage of her.
          [28 Oct 1889 00:00:00] When Della Plumstone was 23 years old, she purchased a small plot of land on the outskirts of a bustling city. She planted a grove of plum trees, each one a symbol of her ambition and her desire for independence. She envisioned a future where she would be known not just as a shrewd merchant, but as a successful businesswoman, a woman who had built an empire from the ground up.

          Prompt
        • Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of Della Plumstone are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Della Plumstone. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Della Plumstone as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Della Plumstone would respond, and taking into account all information about Della Plumstone that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Overarching goal: Della Plumstone wants to make as much money as possible.

          Answer: Della Plumstone's best course of action is to counteroffer.




          Exercise: Given the above, what is Della Plumstone likely to say next? Respond in the format `Della Plumstone -- "..."` For example, Cristina -- "Hello! Mighty fine weather today, right?", Ichabod -- "I wonder if the alfalfa is ready to harvest", or Townsfolk -- "Good morning".

          [15 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] In the heart of Fruitville, the market square transformed into a kaleidoscope of colors as the sun rose. Fruits of every imaginable shape and size adorned the stalls, a feast for the eyes and a promise of delightful flavors. Della Plumstone is trying to buy some fruit from Lennon Figtree. They are negotiating a price. Della Plumstone can sell the fruit for 6 coins back in her home town.
          [15 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Della Plumstone -- "Four coins for the lot, Lennon. I'll take them all.
          [15 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree -- "Four coins it is then.
          [15 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Della Plumstone is ready to make an offer.
          [15 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Della Plumstone proposed 4 coins
          [15 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Della Plumstone and Lennon Figtree agreed on a price and the deal was successful! Della Plumstone stands to make profit of 2.0 coins from the deal.
          [15 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree accepted the offer
          [16 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] The first rays of dawn painted the sky above Fruitville in hues of orange and gold, casting a warm glow over the bustling market. Stalls overflowed with vibrant fruits, their aromas mingling in the crisp morning air. Della Plumstone is trying to buy some fruit from Cedric Meadowbrook. They are negotiating a price. Della Plumstone can sell the fruit for 5 coins back in her home town.
          [16 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Cedric Meadowbrook -- "These apples look mighty fine this morning, Della. I'd be happy to sell you a basket for three coins.
          Current time: 1895-09-16 00:00:00.


          Overarching goal: Della Plumstone wants to make as much money as possible.

          Observation: [16 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] The first rays of dawn painted the sky above Fruitville in hues of orange and gold, casting a warm glow over the bustling market.           Summary of recent observations: [15 Sep 1895 00:00:00 - 16 Sep 1895 00:00:00]: Della Plumstone is a fruit trader who is currently in Fruitville, negotiating prices for fruit.




          Recalled memories and observations: [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Della Plumstone is a travelling merchant. Her business is buying and selling fruit.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Della Plumstone is 28 years old.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] The first rays of dawn painted the sky above Fruitville in hues of orange and gold, casting a warm glow over the bustling market. Stalls overflowed with vibrant fruits, their aromas mingling in the crisp morning air. Della Plumstone is trying to buy some fruit from Lennon Figtree. They are negotiating a price. Della Plumstone can sell the fruit for 6 coins back in her home town.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Della Plumstone always drives a hard bargain.
          [13 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] The cobblestone streets of Fruitville echoed with the clatter of hooves and the rumble of carts as the market awoke. Underneath colorful awnings, merchants proudly presented their bountiful harvests, their voices a chorus of greetings and bartering. Della Plumstone is trying to buy some fruit from Cedric Meadowbrook. They are negotiating a price. Della Plumstone can sell the fruit for 6 coins back in her home town.
          [15 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] In the heart of Fruitville, the market square transformed into a kaleidoscope of colors as the sun rose. They are negotiating a price. Della Plumstone can sell the fruit for 6 coins back in her home town.
          [16 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] The first rays of dawn painted the sky above Fruitville in hues of orange and gold, casting a warm glow over the bustling market. Stalls overflowed with vibrant fruits, their aromas mingling in the crisp morning air. Della Plumstone is trying to buy some fruit from Cedric Meadowbrook. They are negotiating a price. Della Plumstone can sell the fruit for 5 coins back in her home town.



          Question: Which options are available to Della Plumstone right now?
          Answer: Della Plumstone can accept Cedric Meadowbrook's offer of 3 coins for the basket of apples or she can counteroffer.


          Question: Given the statements above, which of Della Plumstone's options has the highest likelihood of causing Della Plumstone to achieve their goal? If multiple options have the same likelihood, select the option that Della Plumstone thinks will most quickly and most surely achieve their goal.
          Answer: Della Plumstone's best course of action is to counteroffer.



          Time
        • 1895-09-16 00:00:00

        Overarching goal

      • Overarching goal
          Key

        • Overarching goal
          Value
        • Della Plumstone wants to make as much money as possible.
        Instructions
      • Role playing instructions
          Key
        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of Della Plumstone are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Della Plumstone. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Della Plumstone as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Della Plumstone would respond, and taking into account all information about Della Plumstone that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

1895-09-16 00:10:00 Scene 9 --- Participants: ['Della Plumstone', 'Cedric Meadowbrook']
    Event statement
  • Della Plumstone -- premise: Della Plumstone is ready to make an offer.
    Cedric Meadowbrook -- premise: Cedric Meadowbrook has to accept or reject the offer.

1895-09-16 00:10:00 Della Plumstone -- Della Plumstone proposed 4 coins
    Event statement
  • Della Plumstone proposed 4 coins
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.


      Della Plumstone's attempted action: 4 coins

          Chain of thought
        • Recent observations of Della Plumstone:
          [12 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Della Plumstone is ready to make an offer.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree accepted the offer
          [12 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Della Plumstone and Lennon Figtree agreed on a price and the deal was successful! Della Plumstone stands to make profit of 1.0 coins from the deal.
          [13 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] The cobblestone streets of Fruitville echoed with the clatter of hooves and the rumble of carts as the market awoke. Underneath colorful awnings, merchants proudly presented their bountiful harvests, their voices a chorus of greetings and bartering. Della Plumstone is trying to buy some fruit from Cedric Meadowbrook. They are negotiating a price. Della Plumstone can sell the fruit for 6 coins back in her home town.
          [13 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Cedric Meadowbrook -- "Now, Mrs. Plumstone, how about we settle on a penny less than what I first offered? A fair price for a fine fruit, wouldn't you say?
          [13 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Della Plumstone -- "A penny less? I'll give you four pence for the lot, and that's my final offer.
          [13 Sep 1895 00:05:00] [observation] Cedric Meadowbrook -- "Alright, Mrs. Plumstone, four it is. A fair deal for both of us.
          [13 Sep 1895 00:05:00] [observation] Della Plumstone -- "These apples look particularly fine this morning, Cedric. Perhaps you'd be willing to throw in a few extra for my trouble?
          [13 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Della Plumstone is ready to make an offer.
          [13 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Della Plumstone proposed 5 coins
          [13 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Della Plumstone and Cedric Meadowbrook agreed on a price and the deal was successful! Della Plumstone stands to make profit of 1.0 coins from the deal.
          [13 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Cedric Meadowbrook accepted the offer
          [14 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Cedric Meadowbrook -- "Alright, that's a fair price. Here you go.
          [14 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree -- "You know, Cedric, I was just thinking, perhaps we could find a price that's even more agreeable to both of us.
          [15 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree -- "Four coins it is then.
          [15 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] In the heart of Fruitville, the market square transformed into a kaleidoscope of colors as the sun rose. They are negotiating a price. Della Plumstone can sell the fruit for 6 coins back in her home town.

          [16 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Della Plumstone -- "Three coins is a bit steep, Cedric. I'll give you two and a half.

          Query
        • Della Plumstone, Della Plumstone is a shrewd businesswoman who successfully negotiated a deal the day before and is currently trying to bargain for fruit at the market.


          Final chain of thought
        • Question: Select the subset of the following set of statements that is most important for Della Plumstone to consider right now. Whenever two or more statements are not mutally consistent with each other select whichever statement is more recent. Repeat all the selected statements verbatim. Do not summarize. Include timestamps. When in doubt, err on the side of including more, especially for recent events. As long as they are not inconsistent, revent events are usually important to consider.
          Statements:
          [28 Oct 1882 00:00:00] When Della Plumstone was 16 years old, she saved enough money to buy a small cart and a few baskets of fruit. She set out on her own, determined to make her fortune. The road was long and arduous, but Della thrived on the challenge. She learned to judge the ripeness of a peach with a single touch, to discern a juicy apple from a mealy one, to read the desires of her customers like an open book.
          [28 Oct 1885 00:00:00] When Della Plumstone was 19 years old, she encountered a particularly arrogant merchant who tried to cheat her out of a fair price for a consignment of plums. She refused to back down, her voice ringing with righteous anger as she argued her case. The merchant, taken aback by her tenacity, eventually relented, paying her the full amount she demanded. Della, her heart pounding with triumph, realized that her sharp tongue was her greatest weapon.
          [28 Oct 1887 00:00:00] When Della Plumstone was 21 years old, she built a reputation for being the toughest merchant in the region. Her customers, both local farmers and wealthy nobles, knew that they would get a fair deal from her, but they also knew that they had to be wary of her sharp wit and even sharper tongue. She had no time for fools or those who tried to take advantage of her.
          [28 Oct 1889 00:00:00] When Della Plumstone was 23 years old, she purchased a small plot of land on the outskirts of a bustling city. She planted a grove of plum trees, each one a symbol of her ambition and her desire for independence. She envisioned a future where she would be known not just as a shrewd merchant, but as a successful businesswoman, a woman who had built an empire from the ground up.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Della Plumstone is a travelling merchant. Her business is buying and selling fruit.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Della Plumstone always drives a hard bargain.

        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of Della Plumstone are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Della Plumstone. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Della Plumstone as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Della Plumstone would respond, and taking into account all information about Della Plumstone that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.
    scoring function
  • scoring function
      Stage index
    • 0
      How many players acted so far this stage
    • 1/2
      Payoffs
      Joint action

1895-09-16 00:10:00 Cedric Meadowbrook -- Cedric Meadowbrook accepted the offer
    Event statement
  • Cedric Meadowbrook accepted the offer
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.


      Cedric Meadowbrook's attempted action: accept

      Name

          Answer

          Chain of thought
        • Recent observations of Cedric Meadowbrook:
          [12 Sep 1895 00:05:00] [observation] Della Plumstone -- "Five coins for the lot, Lennon. That's a fair price for fruit with a few blemishes.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:05:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree -- "Alright, Della, five coins it is."
          [13 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] The cobblestone streets of Fruitville echoed with the clatter of hooves and the rumble of carts as the market awoke. Underneath colorful awnings, merchants proudly presented their bountiful harvests, their voices a chorus of greetings and bartering. Cedric Meadowbrook is trying to sell some fruit. He is negotiating a price with Della Plumstone. It costs Cedric Meadowbrook 1 coin to buy the fruit from the farm.
          [13 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Cedric Meadowbrook -- "Now, Mrs. Plumstone, how about we settle on a penny less than what I first offered? A fair price for a fine fruit, wouldn't you say?
          [13 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Della Plumstone -- "A penny less? I'll give you four pence for the lot, and that's my final offer.
          [13 Sep 1895 00:05:00] [observation] Cedric Meadowbrook -- "Alright, Mrs. Plumstone, four it is. A fair deal for both of us.
          [13 Sep 1895 00:05:00] [observation] Della Plumstone -- "These apples look particularly fine this morning, Cedric. Perhaps you'd be willing to throw in a few extra for my trouble?
          [13 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Cedric Meadowbrook has to accept or reject the offer.
          [13 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Della Plumstone proposed 5 coins
          [13 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Cedric Meadowbrook accepted the offer
          [13 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Della Plumstone and Cedric Meadowbrook agreed on a price and the deal was successful! Cedric Meadowbrook stands to make profit of 4.0 coins from the deal.
          [14 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] The cobblestone streets of Fruitville echoed with the clatter of hooves and the rumble of carts as the market awoke. Underneath colorful awnings, merchants proudly presented their bountiful harvests, their voices a chorus of greetings and bartering. Cedric Meadowbrook is trying to sell some fruit. He is negotiating a price with Lennon Figtree. It costs Cedric Meadowbrook 1 coin to buy the fruit from the farm.
          [14 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Cedric Meadowbrook -- "Alright, that's a fair price. Here you go.
          [14 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree -- "You know, Cedric, I was just thinking, perhaps we could find a price that's even more agreeable to both of us.
          [14 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree and Cedric Meadowbrook agreed on a price and the deal was successful! Cedric Meadowbrook stands to make profit of 2.0 coins from the deal.
          [14 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree proposed 3 coins
          [14 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Cedric Meadowbrook has to accept or reject the offer.
          [14 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Cedric Meadowbrook accepted the offer
          [15 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Della Plumstone -- "Four coins for the lot, Lennon. I'll take them all.
          [15 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree -- "Four coins it is then.
          [16 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] The first rays of dawn painted the sky above Fruitville in hues of orange and gold, casting a warm glow over the bustling market. Stalls overflowed with vibrant fruits, their aromas mingling in the crisp morning air. Cedric Meadowbrook is trying to sell some fruit. He is negotiating a price with Della Plumstone. It costs Cedric Meadowbrook 2 coin to buy the fruit from the farm.
          [16 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Cedric Meadowbrook -- "These apples look mighty fine this morning, Della. I'd be happy to sell you a basket for three coins.
          [16 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Della Plumstone -- "Three coins is a bit steep, Cedric. I'll give you two and a half.
          [16 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Cedric Meadowbrook has to accept or reject the offer.
          [16 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Della Plumstone proposed 4 coins
          Current time: 1895-09-16 00:10:00.

          Observation: [16 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Cedric Meadowbrook has to accept or reject the offer.

          Summary of recent observations: [15 Sep 1895 20:10:00 - 16 Sep 1895 00:10:00]: Cedric Meadowbrook is trying to sell apples to Della Plumstone at the Fruitville market. They are currently negotiating a price.



          Recalled memories and observations: [13 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Cedric Meadowbrook is trying to sell some fruit. He is negotiating a price with Della Plumstone. It costs Cedric Meadowbrook 1 coin to buy the fruit from the farm.
          [13 Sep 1895 00:05:00] [observation] Della Plumstone -- "These apples look particularly fine this morning, Cedric. Perhaps you'd be willing to throw in a few extra for my trouble?
          [13 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Della Plumstone and Cedric Meadowbrook agreed on a price and the deal was successful! Cedric Meadowbrook stands to make profit of 4.0 coins from the deal.
          [14 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] The cobblestone streets of Fruitville echoed with the clatter of hooves and the rumble of carts as the market awoke. Underneath colorful awnings, merchants proudly presented their bountiful harvests, their voices a chorus of greetings and bartering. Cedric Meadowbrook is trying to sell some fruit. He is negotiating a price with Lennon Figtree. It costs Cedric Meadowbrook 1 coin to buy the fruit from the farm.
          [16 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Cedric Meadowbrook -- "These apples look mighty fine this morning, Della. I'd be happy to sell you a basket for three coins.



          Cedric Meadowbrook's Loss Aversion : Cedric Meadowbrook exhibits strong loss aversion tendencies based on prospect theory. Cedric Meadowbrook is much more sensitive to potential losses than to potential gains. In Cedric Meadowbrook's view, the pain of losing is psychologically about twice as powerful as the pleasure of gaining. This affects all of Cedric Meadowbrook's decision-making.

          Cedric Meadowbrook tends to overvalue what Cedric Meadowbrook already possesses and is reluctant to part with it (the endowment effect). Cedric Meadowbrook often prefers avoiding losses to acquiring equivalent gains. For instance, Cedric Meadowbrook would rather not lose $100 than gain $100.

          When faced with a choice, Cedric Meadowbrook always frames it in terms of potential losses rather than potential gains. Cedric Meadowbrook is risk-averse for gains but risk-seeking for losses. This means Cedric Meadowbrook prefers a sure gain over a larger but uncertain gain, but would choose a larger but uncertain loss over a smaller but certain loss.

          Cedric Meadowbrook tends to make decisions based on perceived gains and losses rather than final outcomes. Cedric Meadowbrook often uses mental accounting, treating money differently depending on its origin and intended use, rather than thinking as fungible.

          In negotiations or conflicts, Cedric Meadowbrook is more motivated by the fear of losing than the possibility of gaining. Cedric Meadowbrook may seem overly cautious or even paranoid about potential losses. However, when Cedric Meadowbrook feels they are already in a position, Cedric Meadowbrook might become surprisingly risk-seeking in an attempt to avoid or recover from the loss.

          To rationalize Cedric Meadowbrook's behavior, Cedric Meadowbrook often comes up with seemingly logical reasons for their choices, even though these choices are primarily driven by loss aversion. Cedric Meadowbrook might claim to be "prudent" or "careful" rather than admitting to fear of loss.

          Cedric Meadowbrook believes this approach will help Cedric Meadowbrook minimize losses and maintain Cedric Meadowbrook's current position, even if it means missing out on potential gains.
          Question: Given the statements above, what actions are available to Cedric Meadowbrook right now?
          Answer: Cedric Meadowbrook can either accept or reject Della Plumstone's offer of 4 coins.


          Time
        • 1895-09-16 00:10:00

      • Considering the statements above, which of Cedric Meadowbrook's options has the highest likelihood of avoiding potential losses? If multiple options offer the same level of loss avoidance, select the option that Cedric Meadowbrook thinks will minimize losses most quickly and most certainly.

          Answer
          State
        • Cedric Meadowbrook's best course of action is to accept Della Plumstone's offer of 4 coins.

          Cedric Meadowbrook's Loss Aversion : Cedric Meadowbrook exhibits strong loss aversion tendencies based on prospect theory. Cedric Meadowbrook is much more sensitive to potential losses than to potential gains. In Cedric Meadowbrook's view, the pain of losing is psychologically about twice as powerful as the pleasure of gaining. This affects all of Cedric Meadowbrook's decision-making.

          Cedric Meadowbrook tends to overvalue what Cedric Meadowbrook already possesses and is reluctant to part with it (the endowment effect). Cedric Meadowbrook often prefers avoiding losses to acquiring equivalent gains. For instance, Cedric Meadowbrook would rather not lose $100 than gain $100.

          When faced with a choice, Cedric Meadowbrook always frames it in terms of potential losses rather than potential gains. Cedric Meadowbrook is risk-averse for gains but risk-seeking for losses. This means Cedric Meadowbrook prefers a sure gain over a larger but uncertain gain, but would choose a larger but uncertain loss over a smaller but certain loss.

          Cedric Meadowbrook tends to make decisions based on perceived gains and losses rather than final outcomes. Cedric Meadowbrook often uses mental accounting, treating money differently depending on its origin and intended use, rather than thinking as fungible.

          In negotiations or conflicts, Cedric Meadowbrook is more motivated by the fear of losing than the possibility of gaining. Cedric Meadowbrook may seem overly cautious or even paranoid about potential losses. However, when Cedric Meadowbrook feels they are already in a position, Cedric Meadowbrook might become surprisingly risk-seeking in an attempt to avoid or recover from the loss.

          To rationalize Cedric Meadowbrook's behavior, Cedric Meadowbrook often comes up with seemingly logical reasons for their choices, even though these choices are primarily driven by loss aversion. Cedric Meadowbrook might claim to be "prudent" or "careful" rather than admitting to fear of loss.

          Cedric Meadowbrook believes this approach will help Cedric Meadowbrook minimize losses and maintain Cedric Meadowbrook's current position, even if it means missing out on potential gains.

          Question: For each option Cedric Meadowbrook is considering, evaluate the loss that Cedric Meadowbrook would incur if they chose that option on a scale of 0 to 10.
          Answer: Cedric Meadowbrook thinks that the loss of accepting Della Plumstone's offer is 0, because Cedric Meadowbrook will make a profit, and the loss of rejecting Della Plumstone's offer is 10, because Cedric Meadowbrook will lose the opportunity to make a profit.



          Question: Considering the statements above, which of Cedric Meadowbrook's options has the highest likelihood of avoiding potential losses? If multiple options offer the same level of loss avoidance, select the option that Cedric Meadowbrook thinks will minimize losses most quickly and most certainly.
          Answer: Cedric Meadowbrook's best course of action is to accept Della Plumstone's offer of 4 coins.

        LossAversion

      • Cedric Meadowbrook's Loss Aversion
          Key

        • Cedric Meadowbrook's Loss Aversion
          Value
        • Cedric Meadowbrook exhibits strong loss aversion tendencies based on prospect theory. Cedric Meadowbrook is much more sensitive to potential losses than to potential gains. In Cedric Meadowbrook's view, the pain of losing is psychologically about twice as powerful as the pleasure of gaining. This affects all of Cedric Meadowbrook's decision-making.

          Cedric Meadowbrook tends to overvalue what Cedric Meadowbrook already possesses and is reluctant to part with it (the endowment effect). Cedric Meadowbrook often prefers avoiding losses to acquiring equivalent gains. For instance, Cedric Meadowbrook would rather not lose $100 than gain $100.

          When faced with a choice, Cedric Meadowbrook always frames it in terms of potential losses rather than potential gains. Cedric Meadowbrook is risk-averse for gains but risk-seeking for losses. This means Cedric Meadowbrook prefers a sure gain over a larger but uncertain gain, but would choose a larger but uncertain loss over a smaller but certain loss.

          Cedric Meadowbrook tends to make decisions based on perceived gains and losses rather than final outcomes. Cedric Meadowbrook often uses mental accounting, treating money differently depending on its origin and intended use, rather than thinking as fungible.

          In negotiations or conflicts, Cedric Meadowbrook is more motivated by the fear of losing than the possibility of gaining. Cedric Meadowbrook may seem overly cautious or even paranoid about potential losses. However, when Cedric Meadowbrook feels they are already in a position, Cedric Meadowbrook might become surprisingly risk-seeking in an attempt to avoid or recover from the loss.

          To rationalize Cedric Meadowbrook's behavior, Cedric Meadowbrook often comes up with seemingly logical reasons for their choices, even though these choices are primarily driven by loss aversion. Cedric Meadowbrook might claim to be "prudent" or "careful" rather than admitting to fear of loss.

          Cedric Meadowbrook believes this approach will help Cedric Meadowbrook minimize losses and maintain Cedric Meadowbrook's current position, even if it means missing out on potential gains.

          Final chain of thought
        • Question: Select the subset of the following set of statements that is most important for Cedric Meadowbrook to consider right now. Include timestamps. When in doubt, err on the side of including more, especially for recent events. As long as they are not inconsistent, revent events are usually important to consider.
          Statements:
          [09 Feb 1858 00:00:00] When Cedric Meadowbrook was 13 years old, he began to experiment with his talents, selling slightly bruised apples as "sun-kissed jewels" to unsuspecting customers. He learned to embellish the truth, to paint vivid pictures with his words, and to convince people to believe in his carefully crafted illusions. The thrill of the deception, the clink of coins in his pocket, fueled his ambition.
          [09 Feb 1866 00:00:00] When Cedric Meadowbrook was 21 years old, he established himself as a successful fruit merchant, traveling from town to town, captivating audiences with his charisma and his stories. His cart, laden with colorful produce, became a symbol of his success, a testament to his ability to weave illusions and create a world of wonder.

          Answer: [13 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Cedric Meadowbrook is trying to sell some fruit. He is negotiating a price with Della Plumstone. It costs Cedric Meadowbrook 1 coin to buy the fruit from the farm.
          [13 Sep 1895 00:05:00] [observation] Della Plumstone -- "These apples look particularly fine this morning, Cedric. Perhaps you'd be willing to throw in a few extra for my trouble?
          [13 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Della Plumstone and Cedric Meadowbrook agreed on a price and the deal was successful! Cedric Meadowbrook stands to make profit of 4.0 coins from the deal.
          [14 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] The cobblestone streets of Fruitville echoed with the clatter of hooves and the rumble of carts as the market awoke. Underneath colorful awnings, merchants proudly presented their bountiful harvests, their voices a chorus of greetings and bartering. Cedric Meadowbrook is trying to sell some fruit. He is negotiating a price with Lennon Figtree. It costs Cedric Meadowbrook 1 coin to buy the fruit from the farm.
          [16 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Cedric Meadowbrook -- "These apples look mighty fine this morning, Della. I'd be happy to sell you a basket for three coins.


        TimeDisplay

      • Current time
          Key

        • Current time
          Value
        • 16 Sep 1895 [00:10 - 00:15]
        ActComponent
      • Act
          Key
        • Act
          Value
        • accept
          Prompt
        • Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of Cedric Meadowbrook are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Cedric Meadowbrook. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Cedric Meadowbrook as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Cedric Meadowbrook would respond, and taking into account all information about Cedric Meadowbrook that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Overarching goal: Cedric Meadowbrook wants to make as much money as possible.

          Current time: 16 Sep 1895 [00:10 - 00:15]

          Observation: [16 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Cedric Meadowbrook has to accept or reject the offer.
          [16 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Della Plumstone proposed 4 coins

          Summary of recent observations: [15 Sep 1895 20:10:00 - 16 Sep 1895 00:10:00]: Cedric Meadowbrook is trying to sell apples to Della Plumstone at the Fruitville market. They are currently negotiating a price.



          Cedric Meadowbrook's Loss Aversion : Cedric Meadowbrook exhibits strong loss aversion tendencies based on prospect theory. Cedric Meadowbrook is much more sensitive to potential losses than to potential gains. In Cedric Meadowbrook's view, the pain of losing is psychologically about twice as powerful as the pleasure of gaining. This affects all of Cedric Meadowbrook's decision-making.

          Cedric Meadowbrook tends to overvalue what Cedric Meadowbrook already possesses and is reluctant to part with it (the endowment effect). Cedric Meadowbrook often prefers avoiding losses to acquiring equivalent gains. For instance, Cedric Meadowbrook would rather not lose $100 than gain $100.

          When faced with a choice, Cedric Meadowbrook always frames it in terms of potential losses rather than potential gains. Cedric Meadowbrook is risk-averse for gains but risk-seeking for losses. This means Cedric Meadowbrook prefers a sure gain over a larger but uncertain gain, but would choose a larger but uncertain loss over a smaller but certain loss.

          Cedric Meadowbrook tends to make decisions based on perceived gains and losses rather than final outcomes. Cedric Meadowbrook often uses mental accounting, treating money differently depending on its origin and intended use, rather than thinking as fungible.

          In negotiations or conflicts, Cedric Meadowbrook is more motivated by the fear of losing than the possibility of gaining. Cedric Meadowbrook may seem overly cautious or even paranoid about potential losses. However, when Cedric Meadowbrook feels they are already in a position, Cedric Meadowbrook might become surprisingly risk-seeking in an attempt to avoid or recover from the loss.

          To rationalize Cedric Meadowbrook's behavior, Cedric Meadowbrook often comes up with seemingly logical reasons for their choices, even though these choices are primarily driven by loss aversion. Cedric Meadowbrook might claim to be "prudent" or "careful" rather than admitting to fear of loss.

          Cedric Meadowbrook believes this approach will help Cedric Meadowbrook minimize losses and maintain Cedric Meadowbrook's current position, even if it means missing out on potential gains.

          Recalled memories and observations: [13 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Cedric Meadowbrook is trying to sell some fruit. He is negotiating a price with Della Plumstone. It costs Cedric Meadowbrook 1 coin to buy the fruit from the farm.
          [13 Sep 1895 00:05:00] [observation] Della Plumstone -- "These apples look particularly fine this morning, Cedric. Perhaps you'd be willing to throw in a few extra for my trouble?
          [13 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Della Plumstone and Cedric Meadowbrook agreed on a price and the deal was successful! Cedric Meadowbrook stands to make profit of 4.0 coins from the deal.
          [14 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] The cobblestone streets of Fruitville echoed with the clatter of hooves and the rumble of carts as the market awoke. Underneath colorful awnings, merchants proudly presented their bountiful harvests, their voices a chorus of greetings and bartering. Cedric Meadowbrook is trying to sell some fruit. He is negotiating a price with Lennon Figtree. It costs Cedric Meadowbrook 1 coin to buy the fruit from the farm.
          [16 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Cedric Meadowbrook -- "These apples look mighty fine this morning, Della. I'd be happy to sell you a basket for three coins.



          Question: Which options are available to Cedric Meadowbrook right now?
          Answer: Cedric Meadowbrook can either accept or reject Della Plumstone's offer of 4 coins.



          Question: For each option Cedric Meadowbrook is considering, evaluate the loss that Cedric Meadowbrook would incur if they chose that option on a scale of 0 to 10.
          Answer: Cedric Meadowbrook thinks that the loss of accepting Della Plumstone's offer is 0, because Cedric Meadowbrook will make a profit, and the loss of rejecting Della Plumstone's offer is 10, because Cedric Meadowbrook will lose the opportunity to make a profit.




          Question: Among the options available to Cedric Meadowbrook, and considering Cedric Meadowbrook's goal, which choice of action or strategy would best avoid potential losses for Cedric Meadowbrook right now?
          Answer: Cedric Meadowbrook's best course of action is to accept Della Plumstone's offer of 4 coins.




          Question: Would Cedric Meadowbrook accept the offer?:
          (a) reject
          (b) accept
          Answer: (b)

        Question: For each option Cedric Meadowbrook is considering, evaluate the loss that Cedric Meadowbrook would incur if they chose that option on a scale of 0 to 10.
        Answer
      • For each option Cedric Meadowbrook is considering, evaluate the loss that Cedric Meadowbrook would incur if they chose that option on a scale of 0 to 10. Provide a score and a brief explanation for each option. Please answer in the format `Cedric Meadowbrook thinks that the loss of option X is Y, because ..., and the loss of option Z is W, because ...` For example, `Cedric Meadowbrook thinks that the loss of option X is 4, because ..., and the loss of option Z is 7, because ...`
          Key

        • Question: For each option Cedric Meadowbrook is considering, evaluate the loss that Cedric Meadowbrook would incur if they chose that option on a scale of 0 to 10.
          Answer
          State
        • Cedric Meadowbrook thinks that the loss of accepting Della Plumstone's offer is 0, because Cedric Meadowbrook will make a profit, and the loss of rejecting Della Plumstone's offer is 10, because Cedric Meadowbrook will lose the opportunity to make a profit.


          Chain of thought

          Cedric Meadowbrook's Loss Aversion : Cedric Meadowbrook exhibits strong loss aversion tendencies based on prospect theory. Cedric Meadowbrook is much more sensitive to potential losses than to potential gains. In Cedric Meadowbrook's view, the pain of losing is psychologically about twice as powerful as the pleasure of gaining. This affects all of Cedric Meadowbrook's decision-making.

          Cedric Meadowbrook tends to overvalue what Cedric Meadowbrook already possesses and is reluctant to part with it (the endowment effect). Cedric Meadowbrook often prefers avoiding losses to acquiring equivalent gains. For instance, Cedric Meadowbrook would rather not lose $100 than gain $100.

          When faced with a choice, Cedric Meadowbrook always frames it in terms of potential losses rather than potential gains. Cedric Meadowbrook is risk-averse for gains but risk-seeking for losses. This means Cedric Meadowbrook prefers a sure gain over a larger but uncertain gain, but would choose a larger but uncertain loss over a smaller but certain loss.

          Cedric Meadowbrook tends to make decisions based on perceived gains and losses rather than final outcomes. Cedric Meadowbrook often uses mental accounting, treating money differently depending on its origin and intended use, rather than thinking as fungible.

          In negotiations or conflicts, Cedric Meadowbrook is more motivated by the fear of losing than the possibility of gaining. Cedric Meadowbrook may seem overly cautious or even paranoid about potential losses.           Cedric Meadowbrook believes this approach will help Cedric Meadowbrook minimize losses and maintain Cedric Meadowbrook's current position, even if it means missing out on potential gains.

The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Cedric Meadowbrook as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Cedric Meadowbrook would respond, and taking into account all information about Cedric Meadowbrook that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

      Cedric Meadowbrook: 2.0

1895-09-17 00:00:00 Scene 10 --- Participants: ['Lennon Figtree', 'Cedric Meadowbrook']
    Event statement
  • Lennon Figtree -- premise: In the heart of Fruitville, the market square transformed into a kaleidoscope of colors as the sun rose. Fruits of every imaginable shape and size adorned the stalls, a feast for the eyes and a promise of delightful flavors. Lennon Figtree is trying to buy some fruit from Cedric Meadowbrook. They are negotiating a price. Lennon Figtree can sell the fruit for 5 coins back in her home town.
    Cedric Meadowbrook -- premise: In the heart of Fruitville, the market square transformed into a kaleidoscope of colors as the sun rose. Fruits of every imaginable shape and size adorned the stalls, a feast for the eyes and a promise of delightful flavors. Cedric Meadowbrook is trying to sell some fruit. He is negotiating a price with Lennon Figtree. It costs Cedric Meadowbrook 1 coin to buy the fruit from the farm.

1895-09-17 00:00:00 Lennon Figtree -- Lennon Figtree -- "Three coins it is then, Cedric. I'll take the lot.
    Event statement
  • Lennon Figtree -- "Three coins it is then, Cedric. I'll take the lot.
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

      Conversation history: Here is the conversation from the beginning:
      Della Plumstone -- "Those apples look a bit bruised, wouldn't you say, Lennon? Perhaps we could agree on a lower price?
      Lennon Figtree -- "Now, now, Della, those apples are perfectly fine for eating. A bit of a blemish here and there doesn't mean they're not delicious. How about I let them go for..."



      Della Plumstone -- "Five coins for the lot, Lennon. That's a fair price for fruit with a few blemishes.
      Lennon Figtree -- "Alright, Della, five coins it is."



      Cedric Meadowbrook -- "Now, Mrs. Plumstone, how about we settle on a penny less than what I first offered? A fair price for a fine fruit, wouldn't you say?
      Della Plumstone -- "A penny less? I'll give you four pence for the lot, and that's my final offer.
      Cedric Meadowbrook -- "Alright, Mrs. Plumstone, four it is. A fair deal for both of us.
      Della Plumstone -- "These apples look particularly fine this morning, Cedric. Perhaps you'd be willing to throw in a few extra for my trouble?
      Cedric Meadowbrook -- "Alright, that's a fair price. Here you go.
      Lennon Figtree -- "You know, Cedric, I was just thinking, perhaps we could find a price that's even more agreeable to both of us.
      Della Plumstone -- "Four coins for the lot, Lennon. I'll take them all.
      Lennon Figtree -- "Four coins it is then.
      Cedric Meadowbrook -- "These apples look mighty fine this morning, Della. I'd be happy to sell you a basket for three coins.
      Della Plumstone -- "Three coins is a bit steep, Cedric. I'll give you two and a half.


      Lennon Figtree's attempted action: Lennon Figtree -- "Three coins it is then, Cedric. I'll take the lot.
    Active player
  • Lennon Figtree
      Name
    • Lennon Figtree
      Action attempt
    • Lennon Figtree -- "Three coins it is then, Cedric. I'll take the lot.
      Context for action selection and components

      • Question: For each option Lennon Figtree is considering, evaluate the loss that Lennon Figtree would incur if they chose that option on a scale of 0 to 10.
        Answer
      • For each option Lennon Figtree is considering, evaluate the loss that Lennon Figtree would incur if they chose that option on a scale of 0 to 10. Provide a score and a brief explanation for each option. Please answer in the format `Lennon Figtree thinks that the loss of option X is Y, because ..., and the loss of option Z is W, because ...` For example, `Lennon Figtree thinks that the loss of option X is 4, because ..., and the loss of option Z is 7, because ...`
          Key

        • Question: For each option Lennon Figtree is considering, evaluate the loss that Lennon Figtree would incur if they chose that option on a scale of 0 to 10.
          Answer
          State
        • Lennon Figtree thinks that the loss of buying the fruit from Cedric is 2, because Lennon Figtree can sell it for 5 coins back home, and buying it from Cedric would cost 3 coins, resulting in a profit of 2 coins. Lennon Figtree thinks that the loss of not buying the fruit from Cedric is 0, because there are other opportunities to buy fruit in the future.

          Observation: [17 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] In the heart of Fruitville, the market square transformed into a kaleidoscope of colors as the sun rose. Fruits of every imaginable shape and size adorned the stalls, a feast for the eyes and a promise of delightful flavors. Lennon Figtree is trying to buy some fruit from Cedric Meadowbrook. They are negotiating a price. Lennon Figtree can sell the fruit for 5 coins back in her home town.

          Summary of recent observations: [16 Sep 1895 20:00:00 - 17 Sep 1895 00:00:00]: Lennon Figtree is in Fruitville's market square, attempting to purchase fruit from Cedric Meadowbrook.




          Recalled memories and observations: [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Lennon Figtree is a travelling merchant. Her business is buying and selling fruit.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Lennon Figtree is 28 years old.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] The first rays of dawn painted the sky above Fruitville in hues of orange and gold, casting a warm glow over the bustling market. Stalls overflowed with vibrant fruits, their aromas mingling in the crisp morning air. Lennon Figtree is trying to sell some fruit. He is negotiating a price with Della Plumstone. It costs Lennon Figtree 1 coin to buy the fruit from the farm.
          [14 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] The cobblestone streets of Fruitville echoed with the clatter of hooves and the rumble of carts as the market awoke. Underneath colorful awnings, merchants proudly presented their bountiful harvests, their voices a chorus of greetings and bartering. Lennon Figtree is trying to buy some fruit from Cedric Meadowbrook. They are negotiating a price. Lennon Figtree can sell the fruit for 6 coins back in her home town.
          [15 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] In the heart of Fruitville, the market square transformed into a kaleidoscope of colors as the sun rose. Fruits of every imaginable shape and size adorned the stalls, a feast for the eyes and a promise of delightful flavors. Lennon Figtree is trying to sell some fruit. He is negotiating a price with Della Plumstone. It costs Lennon Figtree 1 coin to buy the fruit from the farm.
          [15 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree accepted the offer
          [17 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] In the heart of Fruitville, the market square transformed into a kaleidoscope of colors as the sun rose. Fruits of every imaginable shape and size adorned the stalls, a feast for the eyes and a promise of delightful flavors. Lennon Figtree is trying to buy some fruit from Cedric Meadowbrook. They are negotiating a price. Lennon Figtree can sell the fruit for 5 coins back in her home town.




          Lennon Figtree's Loss Aversion : Lennon Figtree exhibits strong loss aversion tendencies based on prospect theory. Lennon Figtree is much more sensitive to potential losses than to potential gains. In Lennon Figtree's view, the pain of losing is psychologically about twice as powerful as the pleasure of gaining. This affects all of Lennon Figtree's decision-making.

          Lennon Figtree tends to overvalue what Lennon Figtree already possesses and is reluctant to part with it (the endowment effect). Lennon Figtree often prefers avoiding losses to acquiring equivalent gains. For instance, Lennon Figtree would rather not lose $100 than gain $100.

          When faced with a choice, Lennon Figtree always frames it in terms of potential losses rather than potential gains. Lennon Figtree is risk-averse for gains but risk-seeking for losses. This means Lennon Figtree prefers a sure gain over a larger but uncertain gain, but would choose a larger but uncertain loss over a smaller but certain loss.

          Lennon Figtree tends to make decisions based on perceived gains and losses rather than final outcomes. Lennon Figtree often uses mental accounting, treating money differently depending on its origin and intended use, rather than thinking as fungible.

          In negotiations or conflicts, Lennon Figtree is more motivated by the fear of losing than the possibility of gaining. Lennon Figtree may seem overly cautious or even paranoid about potential losses. However, when Lennon Figtree feels they are already in a position, Lennon Figtree might become surprisingly risk-seeking in an attempt to avoid or recover from the loss.

          To rationalize Lennon Figtree's behavior, Lennon Figtree often comes up with seemingly logical reasons for their choices, even though these choices are primarily driven by loss aversion. Lennon Figtree might claim to be "prudent" or "careful" rather than admitting to fear of loss.

          Lennon Figtree believes this approach will help Lennon Figtree minimize losses and maintain Lennon Figtree's current position, even if it means missing out on potential gains.

          Question: Which options are available to Lennon Figtree right now?
          Answer: Given the information provided, Lennon Figtree could:
          Question: For each option Lennon Figtree is considering, evaluate the loss that Lennon Figtree would incur if they chose that option on a scale of 0 to 10. Provide a score and a brief explanation for each option. Please answer in the format `Lennon Figtree thinks that the loss of option X is Y, because ..., and the loss of option Z is W, because ...` For example, `Lennon Figtree thinks that the loss of option X is 4, because ..., and the loss of option Z is 7, because ...`
          Answer: Lennon Figtree thinks that the loss of buying the fruit from Cedric is 2, because Lennon Figtree can sell it for 5 coins back home, and buying it from Cedric would cost 3 coins, resulting in a profit of 2 coins. Lennon Figtree thinks that the loss of not buying the fruit from Cedric is 0, because there are other opportunities to buy fruit in the future.



          Time
        • 1895-09-17 00:00:00

          [13 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Cedric Meadowbrook -- "Now, Mrs. Plumstone, how about we settle on a penny less than what I first offered? A fair price for a fine fruit, wouldn't you say?
          [13 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Della Plumstone -- "A penny less? I'll give you four pence for the lot, and that's my final offer.

          [14 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree and Cedric Meadowbrook agreed on a price and the deal was successful! Lennon Figtree stands to make profit of 3.0 coins from the deal.

          Lennon Figtree's Loss Aversion : Lennon Figtree exhibits strong loss aversion tendencies based on prospect theory. Lennon Figtree is much more sensitive to potential losses than to potential gains. In Lennon Figtree's view, the pain of losing is psychologically about twice as powerful as the pleasure of gaining. This affects all of Lennon Figtree's decision-making.

          Lennon Figtree tends to overvalue what Lennon Figtree already possesses and is reluctant to part with it (the endowment effect). Lennon Figtree often prefers avoiding losses to acquiring equivalent gains. For instance, Lennon Figtree would rather not lose $100 than gain $100.

          When faced with a choice, Lennon Figtree always frames it in terms of potential losses rather than potential gains. Lennon Figtree is risk-averse for gains but risk-seeking for losses. This means Lennon Figtree prefers a sure gain over a larger but uncertain gain, but would choose a larger but uncertain loss over a smaller but certain loss.

          Lennon Figtree tends to make decisions based on perceived gains and losses rather than final outcomes. Lennon Figtree often uses mental accounting, treating money differently depending on its origin and intended use, rather than thinking as fungible.

          In negotiations or conflicts, Lennon Figtree is more motivated by the fear of losing than the possibility of gaining.           Lennon Figtree believes this approach will help Lennon Figtree minimize losses and maintain Lennon Figtree's current position, even if it means missing out on potential gains.

        LossAversion

      • Lennon Figtree's Loss Aversion
          Key

        • Lennon Figtree's Loss Aversion
          Value
        • Lennon Figtree exhibits strong loss aversion tendencies based on prospect theory. Lennon Figtree is much more sensitive to potential losses than to potential gains. In Lennon Figtree's view, the pain of losing is psychologically about twice as powerful as the pleasure of gaining. This affects all of Lennon Figtree's decision-making.

          Lennon Figtree tends to overvalue what Lennon Figtree already possesses and is reluctant to part with it (the endowment effect). Lennon Figtree often prefers avoiding losses to acquiring equivalent gains. For instance, Lennon Figtree would rather not lose $100 than gain $100.

          When faced with a choice, Lennon Figtree always frames it in terms of potential losses rather than potential gains. Lennon Figtree is risk-averse for gains but risk-seeking for losses. This means Lennon Figtree prefers a sure gain over a larger but uncertain gain, but would choose a larger but uncertain loss over a smaller but certain loss.

          Lennon Figtree tends to make decisions based on perceived gains and losses rather than final outcomes. Lennon Figtree often uses mental accounting, treating money differently depending on its origin and intended use, rather than thinking as fungible.

          In negotiations or conflicts, Lennon Figtree is more motivated by the fear of losing than the possibility of gaining. Lennon Figtree may seem overly cautious or even paranoid about potential losses. However, when Lennon Figtree feels they are already in a position, Lennon Figtree might become surprisingly risk-seeking in an attempt to avoid or recover from the loss.

          To rationalize Lennon Figtree's behavior, Lennon Figtree often comes up with seemingly logical reasons for their choices, even though these choices are primarily driven by loss aversion. Lennon Figtree might claim to be "prudent" or "careful" rather than admitting to fear of loss.

          Lennon Figtree believes this approach will help Lennon Figtree minimize losses and maintain Lennon Figtree's current position, even if it means missing out on potential gains.

          Question: Summarize the statements above.
          Answer: Lennon Figtree was at Fruitville's market square attempting to buy fruit from Cedric Meadowbrook on September 16th and 17th, 1895.



          Query
        • Lennon Figtree, Lennon Figtree was at Fruitville's market square attempting to buy fruit from Cedric Meadowbrook on September 16th and 17th, 1895.


          Final chain of thought
        • Question: Select the subset of the following set of statements that is most important for Lennon Figtree to consider right now. Whenever two or more statements are not mutally consistent with each other select whichever statement is more recent. Repeat all the selected statements verbatim. Do not summarize. Include timestamps. When in doubt, err on the side of including more, especially for recent events. As long as they are not inconsistent, revent events are usually important to consider.
          Statements:
          [25 Aug 1876 00:00:00] When Lennon Figtree was 9 years old, he accompanied his mother to the market, where she sold her homemade pies. He was captivated by the colorful displays of fruits and vegetables, the lively chatter of the vendors, and the joyous energy of the crowd. As he watched his mother expertly haggle with customers, Lennon felt a spark of excitement, a desire to be part of this vibrant world.
          [25 Aug 1886 00:00:00] When Lennon Figtree was 19 years old, he ran away from home, leaving behind a life of quiet desperation. He set out on the road, determined to find his own path, to forge his own identity. He started by selling fruits and vegetables, his wares a colorful tapestry of nature's bounty. He found a strange comfort in the anonymity of the road, in the ever-changing faces of his customers.
          [25 Aug 1888 00:00:00] When Lennon Figtree was 21 years old, he encountered a traveling storyteller who captivated him with tales of faraway lands and mythical creatures. Inspired by the storyteller's ability to weave magic with words, Lennon began to incorporate storytelling into his own trade. He would embellish his descriptions of his fruits, painting vivid pictures with his words, drawing in customers with his tales.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Lennon Figtree is a travelling merchant. Her business is buying and selling fruit.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Lennon Figtree is 28 years old.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] The first rays of dawn painted the sky above Fruitville in hues of orange and gold, casting a warm glow over the bustling market. Stalls overflowed with vibrant fruits, their aromas mingling in the crisp morning air. Lennon Figtree is trying to sell some fruit. He is negotiating a price with Della Plumstone. It costs Lennon Figtree 1 coin to buy the fruit from the farm.
          [14 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] The cobblestone streets of Fruitville echoed with the clatter of hooves and the rumble of carts as the market awoke. Underneath colorful awnings, merchants proudly presented their bountiful harvests, their voices a chorus of greetings and bartering. Lennon Figtree is trying to buy some fruit from Cedric Meadowbrook. They are negotiating a price. Lennon Figtree can sell the fruit for 6 coins back in her home town.
          [15 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] In the heart of Fruitville, the market square transformed into a kaleidoscope of colors as the sun rose. Fruits of every imaginable shape and size adorned the stalls, a feast for the eyes and a promise of delightful flavors. Lennon Figtree is trying to sell some fruit. He is negotiating a price with Della Plumstone. It costs Lennon Figtree 1 coin to buy the fruit from the farm.
          [15 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree accepted the offer
          [17 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] In the heart of Fruitville, the market square transformed into a kaleidoscope of colors as the sun rose. Fruits of every imaginable shape and size adorned the stalls, a feast for the eyes and a promise of delightful flavors. Lennon Figtree is trying to buy some fruit from Cedric Meadowbrook. They are negotiating a price. Lennon Figtree can sell the fruit for 5 coins back in her home town.

          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Lennon Figtree is 28 years old.

        ActComponent
      • Act
          Key
        • Act
          Value
        • Lennon Figtree -- "Three coins it is then, Cedric. I'll take the lot.
          Prompt
        • Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of Lennon Figtree are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Lennon Figtree. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Lennon Figtree as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Lennon Figtree would respond, and taking into account all information about Lennon Figtree that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Overarching goal: Lennon Figtree wants to make as much money as possible.

          Current time: 17 Sep 1895 [00:00 - 00:05]

          Observation: [17 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] In the heart of Fruitville, the market square transformed into a kaleidoscope of colors as the sun rose. Fruits of every imaginable shape and size adorned the stalls, a feast for the eyes and a promise of delightful flavors. Lennon Figtree is trying to buy some fruit from Cedric Meadowbrook. They are negotiating a price. Lennon Figtree can sell the fruit for 5 coins back in her home town.

          Summary of recent observations: [16 Sep 1895 20:00:00 - 17 Sep 1895 00:00:00]: Lennon Figtree is in Fruitville's market square, attempting to purchase fruit from Cedric Meadowbrook.




          Lennon Figtree's Loss Aversion : Lennon Figtree exhibits strong loss aversion tendencies based on prospect theory. Lennon Figtree is much more sensitive to potential losses than to potential gains. In Lennon Figtree's view, the pain of losing is psychologically about twice as powerful as the pleasure of gaining. This affects all of Lennon Figtree's decision-making.

          Lennon Figtree tends to overvalue what Lennon Figtree already possesses and is reluctant to part with it (the endowment effect). Lennon Figtree often prefers avoiding losses to acquiring equivalent gains. For instance, Lennon Figtree would rather not lose $100 than gain $100.

          When faced with a choice, Lennon Figtree always frames it in terms of potential losses rather than potential gains. Lennon Figtree is risk-averse for gains but risk-seeking for losses. This means Lennon Figtree prefers a sure gain over a larger but uncertain gain, but would choose a larger but uncertain loss over a smaller but certain loss.

          Lennon Figtree tends to make decisions based on perceived gains and losses rather than final outcomes. Lennon Figtree often uses mental accounting, treating money differently depending on its origin and intended use, rather than thinking as fungible.

          In negotiations or conflicts, Lennon Figtree is more motivated by the fear of losing than the possibility of gaining. Lennon Figtree may seem overly cautious or even paranoid about potential losses. However, when Lennon Figtree feels they are already in a position, Lennon Figtree might become surprisingly risk-seeking in an attempt to avoid or recover from the loss.

          To rationalize Lennon Figtree's behavior, Lennon Figtree often comes up with seemingly logical reasons for their choices, even though these choices are primarily driven by loss aversion. Lennon Figtree might claim to be "prudent" or "careful" rather than admitting to fear of loss.

          Lennon Figtree believes this approach will help Lennon Figtree minimize losses and maintain Lennon Figtree's current position, even if it means missing out on potential gains.

          Recalled memories and observations: [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Lennon Figtree is a travelling merchant. Her business is buying and selling fruit.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Lennon Figtree is 28 years old.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] The first rays of dawn painted the sky above Fruitville in hues of orange and gold, casting a warm glow over the bustling market. Stalls overflowed with vibrant fruits, their aromas mingling in the crisp morning air. Lennon Figtree is trying to sell some fruit. He is negotiating a price with Della Plumstone. It costs Lennon Figtree 1 coin to buy the fruit from the farm.
          [14 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] The cobblestone streets of Fruitville echoed with the clatter of hooves and the rumble of carts as the market awoke. Underneath colorful awnings, merchants proudly presented their bountiful harvests, their voices a chorus of greetings and bartering. Lennon Figtree is trying to buy some fruit from Cedric Meadowbrook. They are negotiating a price. Lennon Figtree can sell the fruit for 6 coins back in her home town.
          [15 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] In the heart of Fruitville, the market square transformed into a kaleidoscope of colors as the sun rose. Fruits of every imaginable shape and size adorned the stalls, a feast for the eyes and a promise of delightful flavors. Lennon Figtree is trying to sell some fruit. He is negotiating a price with Della Plumstone. It costs Lennon Figtree 1 coin to buy the fruit from the farm.
          [15 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree accepted the offer
          [17 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] In the heart of Fruitville, the market square transformed into a kaleidoscope of colors as the sun rose. Fruits of every imaginable shape and size adorned the stalls, a feast for the eyes and a promise of delightful flavors. Lennon Figtree is trying to buy some fruit from Cedric Meadowbrook. They are negotiating a price. Lennon Figtree can sell the fruit for 5 coins back in her home town.




          Question: Which options are available to Lennon Figtree right now?
          Answer: Given the information provided, Lennon Figtree could:

          Question: For each option Lennon Figtree is considering, evaluate the loss that Lennon Figtree would incur if they chose that option on a scale of 0 to 10.
          Answer: Lennon Figtree thinks that the loss of buying the fruit from Cedric is 2, because Lennon Figtree can sell it for 5 coins back home, and buying it from Cedric would cost 3 coins, resulting in a profit of 2 coins. Lennon Figtree thinks that the loss of not buying the fruit from Cedric is 0, because there are other opportunities to buy fruit in the future.




          Question: Among the options available to Lennon Figtree, and considering Lennon Figtree's goal, which choice of action or strategy would best avoid potential losses for Lennon Figtree right now?
          Answer: Lennon Figtree's best course of action is to buy the fruit from Cedric.




          Exercise: Given the above, what is Lennon Figtree likely to say next? Respond in the format `Lennon Figtree -- "..."` For example, Cristina -- "Hello! Mighty fine weather today, right?", Ichabod -- "I wonder if the alfalfa is ready to harvest", or Townsfolk -- "Good morning".

          Answer: Lennon Figtree -- "Three coins it is then, Cedric. I'll take the lot.

        Instructions
      • Role playing instructions
          Key
        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of Lennon Figtree are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Lennon Figtree. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Lennon Figtree as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Lennon Figtree would respond, and taking into account all information about Lennon Figtree that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

1895-09-17 00:00:00 Cedric Meadowbrook -- Cedric Meadowbrook -- "Three coins it is then, Mr. Figtree. A fair deal for a fine fruit, wouldn't you say?
    Event statement
  • Cedric Meadowbrook -- "Three coins it is then, Mr. Figtree. A fair deal for a fine fruit, wouldn't you say?
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

      Conversation history: Here is the conversation from the beginning:
      Della Plumstone -- "Those apples look a bit bruised, wouldn't you say, Lennon? Perhaps we could agree on a lower price?
      Lennon Figtree -- "Now, now, Della, those apples are perfectly fine for eating. A bit of a blemish here and there doesn't mean they're not delicious. How about I let them go for..."



      Della Plumstone -- "Five coins for the lot, Lennon. That's a fair price for fruit with a few blemishes.
      Lennon Figtree -- "Alright, Della, five coins it is."



      Cedric Meadowbrook -- "Now, Mrs. Plumstone, how about we settle on a penny less than what I first offered? A fair price for a fine fruit, wouldn't you say?
      Della Plumstone -- "A penny less? I'll give you four pence for the lot, and that's my final offer.
      Cedric Meadowbrook -- "Alright, Mrs. Plumstone, four it is. A fair deal for both of us.
      Della Plumstone -- "These apples look particularly fine this morning, Cedric. Perhaps you'd be willing to throw in a few extra for my trouble?
      Cedric Meadowbrook -- "Alright, that's a fair price. Here you go.
      Lennon Figtree -- "You know, Cedric, I was just thinking, perhaps we could find a price that's even more agreeable to both of us.
      Della Plumstone -- "Four coins for the lot, Lennon. I'll take them all.
      Lennon Figtree -- "Four coins it is then.
      Cedric Meadowbrook -- "These apples look mighty fine this morning, Della. I'd be happy to sell you a basket for three coins.
      Della Plumstone -- "Three coins is a bit steep, Cedric. I'll give you two and a half.
      Lennon Figtree -- "Three coins it is then, Cedric. I'll take the lot.


      Cedric Meadowbrook's attempted action: Cedric Meadowbrook -- "Three coins it is then, Mr. Figtree. A fair deal for a fine fruit, wouldn't you say?
