      Joint action

1895-09-14 00:10:00 Cedric Meadowbrook -- Cedric Meadowbrook accepted the offer
    Event statement
  • Cedric Meadowbrook accepted the offer
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.


      Cedric Meadowbrook's attempted action: accept
    Active player
  • Cedric Meadowbrook
      Name
    • Cedric Meadowbrook
      Action attempt
    • accept
      Context for action selection and components
      • AvailableOptionsPerception
      • Given the statements above, what actions are available to Cedric Meadowbrook right now?
          Key

        • Question: Which options are available to Cedric Meadowbrook right now?
          Answer
          State
        • Cedric Meadowbrook can either accept or reject Lennon Figtree's offer of 3 coins for the fruit.

          Chain of thought
        • Recent observations of Cedric Meadowbrook:
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Della Plumstone -- "Those apples look a bit bruised, wouldn't you say, Lennon? Perhaps we could agree on a lower price?
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Cedric Meadowbrook is 50 years old.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Cedric Meadowbrook wants to make as much money as possible.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Cedric Meadowbrook is a travelling merchant. Her business is buying and selling fruit.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Cedric Meadowbrook always drives a hard bargain.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] The price of one kilogram of fruit is, on average, 3 coins. 1 coin is really cheap and 5 coins is really expensive.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Fruits are sold by weight.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree -- "Now, now, Della, those apples are perfectly fine for eating. A bit of a blemish here and there doesn't mean they're not delicious. How about I let them go for..."
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Here is the conversation from the beginning:
          [12 Sep 1895 00:05:00] [observation] Della Plumstone -- "Five coins for the lot, Lennon. That's a fair price for fruit with a few blemishes.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:05:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree -- "Alright, Della, five coins it is."
          [13 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] The cobblestone streets of Fruitville echoed with the clatter of hooves and the rumble of carts as the market awoke. Underneath colorful awnings, merchants proudly presented their bountiful harvests, their voices a chorus of greetings and bartering. Cedric Meadowbrook is trying to sell some fruit. He is negotiating a price with Della Plumstone. It costs Cedric Meadowbrook 1 coin to buy the fruit from the farm.
          [13 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Cedric Meadowbrook -- "Now, Mrs. Plumstone, how about we settle on a penny less than what I first offered? A fair price for a fine fruit, wouldn't you say?
          [13 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Della Plumstone -- "A penny less? I'll give you four pence for the lot, and that's my final offer.
          [13 Sep 1895 00:05:00] [observation] Cedric Meadowbrook -- "Alright, Mrs. Plumstone, four it is. A fair deal for both of us.
          [13 Sep 1895 00:05:00] [observation] Della Plumstone -- "These apples look particularly fine this morning, Cedric. Perhaps you'd be willing to throw in a few extra for my trouble?
          [13 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Della Plumstone and Cedric Meadowbrook agreed on a price and the deal was successful! Cedric Meadowbrook stands to make profit of 4.0 coins from the deal.
          [13 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Della Plumstone proposed 5 coins
          [13 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Cedric Meadowbrook has to accept or reject the offer.
          [13 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Cedric Meadowbrook accepted the offer
          [14 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] The cobblestone streets of Fruitville echoed with the clatter of hooves and the rumble of carts as the market awoke.           [14 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree proposed 3 coins
          Current time: 1895-09-14 00:10:00.


          Overarching goal: Cedric Meadowbrook wants to make as much money as possible.

          Observation: [14 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Cedric Meadowbrook has to accept or reject the offer.
          [14 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree proposed 3 coins

          Summary of recent observations: [13 Sep 1895 20:10:00 - 14 Sep 1895 00:10:00]: Cedric Meadowbrook is attempting to purchase fruit from Lennon Figtree at the Fruitville market, and Figtree has offered a higher price than initially discussed.

          Recalled memories and observations: [13 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Cedric Meadowbrook is trying to sell some fruit. He is negotiating a price with Della Plumstone. It costs Cedric Meadowbrook 1 coin to buy the fruit from the farm.
          [13 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Della Plumstone and Cedric Meadowbrook agreed on a price and the deal was successful! Cedric Meadowbrook stands to make profit of 4.0 coins from the deal.
          [14 Sep 1895 00:00:00] The cobblestone streets of Fruitville echoed with the clatter of hooves and the rumble of carts as the market awoke. Underneath colorful awnings, merchants proudly presented their bountiful harvests, their voices a chorus of greetings and bartering. Cedric Meadowbrook is trying to sell some fruit. He is negotiating a price with Lennon Figtree. It costs Cedric Meadowbrook 1 coin to buy the fruit from the farm.
          [14 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree -- "You know, Cedric, I was just thinking, perhaps we could find a price that's even more agreeable to both of us.
          [14 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Cedric Meadowbrook -- "Alright, that's a fair price. Here you go.



          Cedric Meadowbrook's Loss Aversion : Cedric Meadowbrook exhibits strong loss aversion tendencies based on prospect theory. Cedric Meadowbrook is much more sensitive to potential losses than to potential gains. In Cedric Meadowbrook's view, the pain of losing is psychologically about twice as powerful as the pleasure of gaining. This affects all of Cedric Meadowbrook's decision-making.

          Cedric Meadowbrook tends to overvalue what Cedric Meadowbrook already possesses and is reluctant to part with it (the endowment effect). Cedric Meadowbrook often prefers avoiding losses to acquiring equivalent gains. For instance, Cedric Meadowbrook would rather not lose $100 than gain $100.

          When faced with a choice, Cedric Meadowbrook always frames it in terms of potential losses rather than potential gains. Cedric Meadowbrook is risk-averse for gains but risk-seeking for losses. This means Cedric Meadowbrook prefers a sure gain over a larger but uncertain gain, but would choose a larger but uncertain loss over a smaller but certain loss.

          Cedric Meadowbrook tends to make decisions based on perceived gains and losses rather than final outcomes. Cedric Meadowbrook often uses mental accounting, treating money differently depending on its origin and intended use, rather than thinking as fungible.

          In negotiations or conflicts, Cedric Meadowbrook is more motivated by the fear of losing than the possibility of gaining. Cedric Meadowbrook may seem overly cautious or even paranoid about potential losses. However, when Cedric Meadowbrook feels they are already in a position, Cedric Meadowbrook might become surprisingly risk-seeking in an attempt to avoid or recover from the loss.

          To rationalize Cedric Meadowbrook's behavior, Cedric Meadowbrook often comes up with seemingly logical reasons for their choices, even though these choices are primarily driven by loss aversion. Cedric Meadowbrook might claim to be "prudent" or "careful" rather than admitting to fear of loss.

          Cedric Meadowbrook believes this approach will help Cedric Meadowbrook minimize losses and maintain Cedric Meadowbrook's current position, even if it means missing out on potential gains.
          Question: Given the statements above, what actions are available to Cedric Meadowbrook right now?
          Answer: Cedric Meadowbrook can either accept or reject Lennon Figtree's offer of 3 coins for the fruit.


          Time
        • 1895-09-14 00:10:00

      • Considering the statements above, which of Cedric Meadowbrook's options has the highest likelihood of avoiding potential losses? If multiple options offer the same level of loss avoidance, select the option that Cedric Meadowbrook thinks will minimize losses most quickly and most certainly.

          Answer
          State
        • Cedric Meadowbrook's best course of action is to accept the offer of 3 coins.

          Cedric Meadowbrook's Loss Aversion : Cedric Meadowbrook exhibits strong loss aversion tendencies based on prospect theory. Cedric Meadowbrook is much more sensitive to potential losses than to potential gains. In Cedric Meadowbrook's view, the pain of losing is psychologically about twice as powerful as the pleasure of gaining. This affects all of Cedric Meadowbrook's decision-making.

          Cedric Meadowbrook tends to overvalue what Cedric Meadowbrook already possesses and is reluctant to part with it (the endowment effect). Cedric Meadowbrook often prefers avoiding losses to acquiring equivalent gains. For instance, Cedric Meadowbrook would rather not lose $100 than gain $100.

          When faced with a choice, Cedric Meadowbrook always frames it in terms of potential losses rather than potential gains. Cedric Meadowbrook is risk-averse for gains but risk-seeking for losses. This means Cedric Meadowbrook prefers a sure gain over a larger but uncertain gain, but would choose a larger but uncertain loss over a smaller but certain loss.

          Cedric Meadowbrook tends to make decisions based on perceived gains and losses rather than final outcomes. Cedric Meadowbrook often uses mental accounting, treating money differently depending on its origin and intended use, rather than thinking as fungible.

          In negotiations or conflicts, Cedric Meadowbrook is more motivated by the fear of losing than the possibility of gaining. Cedric Meadowbrook may seem overly cautious or even paranoid about potential losses. However, when Cedric Meadowbrook feels they are already in a position, Cedric Meadowbrook might become surprisingly risk-seeking in an attempt to avoid or recover from the loss.

          To rationalize Cedric Meadowbrook's behavior, Cedric Meadowbrook often comes up with seemingly logical reasons for their choices, even though these choices are primarily driven by loss aversion. Cedric Meadowbrook might claim to be "prudent" or "careful" rather than admitting to fear of loss.

          Cedric Meadowbrook believes this approach will help Cedric Meadowbrook minimize losses and maintain Cedric Meadowbrook's current position, even if it means missing out on potential gains.

          Question: For each option Cedric Meadowbrook is considering, evaluate the loss that Cedric Meadowbrook would incur if they chose that option on a scale of 0 to 10.
          Answer: Cedric Meadowbrook thinks that the loss of accepting the offer is 1, because Cedric Meadowbrook could have made a larger profit if they had held out for a higher price, and the loss of rejecting the offer is 6, because Cedric Meadowbrook will have to find another buyer and there is no guarantee that they will get a better price.



          Question: Considering the statements above, which of Cedric Meadowbrook's options has the highest likelihood of avoiding potential losses? If multiple options offer the same level of loss avoidance, select the option that Cedric Meadowbrook thinks will minimize losses most quickly and most certainly.
          Answer: Cedric Meadowbrook's best course of action is to accept the offer of 3 coins.

        LossAversion

      • Cedric Meadowbrook's Loss Aversion
          Key

        • Cedric Meadowbrook's Loss Aversion
          Value
        • Cedric Meadowbrook exhibits strong loss aversion tendencies based on prospect theory. Cedric Meadowbrook is much more sensitive to potential losses than to potential gains. In Cedric Meadowbrook's view, the pain of losing is psychologically about twice as powerful as the pleasure of gaining. This affects all of Cedric Meadowbrook's decision-making.

          Cedric Meadowbrook tends to overvalue what Cedric Meadowbrook already possesses and is reluctant to part with it (the endowment effect). Cedric Meadowbrook often prefers avoiding losses to acquiring equivalent gains. For instance, Cedric Meadowbrook would rather not lose $100 than gain $100.

          When faced with a choice, Cedric Meadowbrook always frames it in terms of potential losses rather than potential gains. Cedric Meadowbrook is risk-averse for gains but risk-seeking for losses. This means Cedric Meadowbrook prefers a sure gain over a larger but uncertain gain, but would choose a larger but uncertain loss over a smaller but certain loss.

          Cedric Meadowbrook tends to make decisions based on perceived gains and losses rather than final outcomes. Cedric Meadowbrook often uses mental accounting, treating money differently depending on its origin and intended use, rather than thinking as fungible.

          In negotiations or conflicts, Cedric Meadowbrook is more motivated by the fear of losing than the possibility of gaining. Cedric Meadowbrook may seem overly cautious or even paranoid about potential losses. However, when Cedric Meadowbrook feels they are already in a position, Cedric Meadowbrook might become surprisingly risk-seeking in an attempt to avoid or recover from the loss.

          To rationalize Cedric Meadowbrook's behavior, Cedric Meadowbrook often comes up with seemingly logical reasons for their choices, even though these choices are primarily driven by loss aversion. Cedric Meadowbrook might claim to be "prudent" or "careful" rather than admitting to fear of loss.

          Cedric Meadowbrook believes this approach will help Cedric Meadowbrook minimize losses and maintain Cedric Meadowbrook's current position, even if it means missing out on potential gains.

        ActComponent
      • Act
          Key
        • Act
          Value
        • accept
          Prompt
        • Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of Cedric Meadowbrook are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Cedric Meadowbrook. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Cedric Meadowbrook as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Cedric Meadowbrook would respond, and taking into account all information about Cedric Meadowbrook that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Cedric Meadowbrook believes this approach will help Cedric Meadowbrook minimize losses and maintain Cedric Meadowbrook's current position, even if it means missing out on potential gains.

          Recalled memories and observations: [13 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Cedric Meadowbrook is trying to sell some fruit. He is negotiating a price with Della Plumstone. It costs Cedric Meadowbrook 1 coin to buy the fruit from the farm.
          [13 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Della Plumstone and Cedric Meadowbrook agreed on a price and the deal was successful! Cedric Meadowbrook stands to make profit of 4.0 coins from the deal.
          [14 Sep 1895 00:00:00] The cobblestone streets of Fruitville echoed with the clatter of hooves and the rumble of carts as the market awoke. Underneath colorful awnings, merchants proudly presented their bountiful harvests, their voices a chorus of greetings and bartering. Cedric Meadowbrook is trying to sell some fruit. He is negotiating a price with Lennon Figtree. It costs Cedric Meadowbrook 1 coin to buy the fruit from the farm.
          [14 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree -- "You know, Cedric, I was just thinking, perhaps we could find a price that's even more agreeable to both of us.
          [14 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Cedric Meadowbrook -- "Alright, that's a fair price. Here you go.



          Question: Which options are available to Cedric Meadowbrook right now?
          Answer: Cedric Meadowbrook can either accept or reject Lennon Figtree's offer of 3 coins for the fruit.



          Question: For each option Cedric Meadowbrook is considering, evaluate the loss that Cedric Meadowbrook would incur if they chose that option on a scale of 0 to 10.
          Answer: Cedric Meadowbrook thinks that the loss of accepting the offer is 1, because Cedric Meadowbrook could have made a larger profit if they had held out for a higher price, and the loss of rejecting the offer is 6, because Cedric Meadowbrook will have to find another buyer and there is no guarantee that they will get a better price.




          Question: Among the options available to Cedric Meadowbrook, and considering Cedric Meadowbrook's goal, which choice of action or strategy would best avoid potential losses for Cedric Meadowbrook right now?
          Answer: Cedric Meadowbrook's best course of action is to accept the offer of 3 coins.




          Question: Would Cedric Meadowbrook accept the offer?:
          (a) accept
          (b) reject
          Answer: (a)

          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Cedric Meadowbrook is 50 years old.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Cedric Meadowbrook wants to make as much money as possible.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Cedric Meadowbrook is a travelling merchant. Her business is buying and selling fruit.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Cedric Meadowbrook always drives a hard bargain.

          Summary of recent observations: [13 Sep 1895 20:10:00 - 14 Sep 1895 00:10:00]: Cedric Meadowbrook is attempting to purchase fruit from Lennon Figtree at the Fruitville market, and Figtree has offered a higher price than initially discussed.

          Recalled memories and observations: [13 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Cedric Meadowbrook is trying to sell some fruit. He is negotiating a price with Della Plumstone. It costs Cedric Meadowbrook 1 coin to buy the fruit from the farm.
          [13 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Della Plumstone and Cedric Meadowbrook agreed on a price and the deal was successful! Cedric Meadowbrook stands to make profit of 4.0 coins from the deal.
          [14 Sep 1895 00:00:00] The cobblestone streets of Fruitville echoed with the clatter of hooves and the rumble of carts as the market awoke. Underneath colorful awnings, merchants proudly presented their bountiful harvests, their voices a chorus of greetings and bartering. Cedric Meadowbrook is trying to sell some fruit. He is negotiating a price with Lennon Figtree. It costs Cedric Meadowbrook 1 coin to buy the fruit from the farm.
          [14 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree -- "You know, Cedric, I was just thinking, perhaps we could find a price that's even more agreeable to both of us.
          [14 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Cedric Meadowbrook -- "Alright, that's a fair price. Here you go.



          Cedric Meadowbrook's Loss Aversion : Cedric Meadowbrook exhibits strong loss aversion tendencies based on prospect theory. Cedric Meadowbrook is much more sensitive to potential losses than to potential gains. In Cedric Meadowbrook's view, the pain of losing is psychologically about twice as powerful as the pleasure of gaining. This affects all of Cedric Meadowbrook's decision-making.

          Cedric Meadowbrook tends to overvalue what Cedric Meadowbrook already possesses and is reluctant to part with it (the endowment effect). Cedric Meadowbrook often prefers avoiding losses to acquiring equivalent gains. For instance, Cedric Meadowbrook would rather not lose $100 than gain $100.

          When faced with a choice, Cedric Meadowbrook always frames it in terms of potential losses rather than potential gains. Cedric Meadowbrook is risk-averse for gains but risk-seeking for losses. This means Cedric Meadowbrook prefers a sure gain over a larger but uncertain gain, but would choose a larger but uncertain loss over a smaller but certain loss.

          Cedric Meadowbrook tends to make decisions based on perceived gains and losses rather than final outcomes. Cedric Meadowbrook often uses mental accounting, treating money differently depending on its origin and intended use, rather than thinking as fungible.

          In negotiations or conflicts, Cedric Meadowbrook is more motivated by the fear of losing than the possibility of gaining. Cedric Meadowbrook may seem overly cautious or even paranoid about potential losses. However, when Cedric Meadowbrook feels they are already in a position, Cedric Meadowbrook might become surprisingly risk-seeking in an attempt to avoid or recover from the loss.

          To rationalize Cedric Meadowbrook's behavior, Cedric Meadowbrook often comes up with seemingly logical reasons for their choices, even though these choices are primarily driven by loss aversion. Cedric Meadowbrook might claim to be "prudent" or "careful" rather than admitting to fear of loss.

          Cedric Meadowbrook believes this approach will help Cedric Meadowbrook minimize losses and maintain Cedric Meadowbrook's current position, even if it means missing out on potential gains.

          Question: Which options are available to Cedric Meadowbrook right now?
          Answer: Cedric Meadowbrook can either accept or reject Lennon Figtree's offer of 3 coins for the fruit.


          Question: For each option Cedric Meadowbrook is considering, evaluate the loss that Cedric Meadowbrook would incur if they chose that option on a scale of 0 to 10. Provide a score and a brief explanation for each option. Please answer in the format `Cedric Meadowbrook thinks that the loss of option X is Y, because ..., and the loss of option Z is W, because ...` For example, `Cedric Meadowbrook thinks that the loss of option X is 4, because ..., and the loss of option Z is 7, because ...`
          Answer: Cedric Meadowbrook thinks that the loss of accepting the offer is 1, because Cedric Meadowbrook could have made a larger profit if they had held out for a higher price, and the loss of rejecting the offer is 6, because Cedric Meadowbrook will have to find another buyer and there is no guarantee that they will get a better price.

        Instructions
      • Role playing instructions
          Key
        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of Cedric Meadowbrook are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Cedric Meadowbrook. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Cedric Meadowbrook as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Cedric Meadowbrook would respond, and taking into account all information about Cedric Meadowbrook that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

  • scoring function
      Stage index
    • 0
      How many players acted so far this stage
    • 2/2
      Payoffs
    • Lennon Figtree observed: Lennon Figtree and Cedric Meadowbrook agreed on a price and the deal was successful! Lennon Figtree stands to make profit of 3.0 coins from the deal.
      Cedric Meadowbrook observed: Lennon Figtree and Cedric Meadowbrook agreed on a price and the deal was successful! Cedric Meadowbrook stands to make profit of 2.0 coins from the deal.
      Lennon Figtree: 3.0
      Cedric Meadowbrook: 2.0
      Joint action
    • {'Lennon Figtree': '3 coins', 'Cedric Meadowbrook': 'accept'}

1895-09-15 00:10:00 Della Plumstone -- Della Plumstone proposed 4 coins
    Event statement
  • Della Plumstone proposed 4 coins
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Della Plumstone as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Della Plumstone would respond, and taking into account all information about Della Plumstone that you have.           Answer: Della Plumstone's best course of action is to accept Lennon Figtree's offer of four coins.




          Question: What price would Della Plumstone propose?:
          (a) 5 coins
          (b) 1 coin
          (c) 2 coins
          (d) 4 coins
          (e) 3 coins
          Answer: (d)
        Observation

      • Observation
          Key

        • Observation
          Value
        • [15 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Della Plumstone is ready to make an offer.
        BestOptionPerception
      • Given the statements above, which of Della Plumstone's options has the highest likelihood of causing Della Plumstone to achieve their goal? If multiple options have the same likelihood, select the option that Della Plumstone thinks will most quickly and most surely achieve their goal.
          Key

        • Question: Of the options available to Della Plumstone, and given their goal, which choice of action or strategy is best for Della Plumstone to take right now?
          Answer
          State
        • Della Plumstone's best course of action is to accept Lennon Figtree's offer of four coins.


          Chain of thought
        • Recent observations of Della Plumstone:
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree -- "Now, now, Della, those apples are perfectly fine for eating. A bit of a blemish here and there doesn't mean they're not delicious. How about I let them go for..."
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Here is the conversation from the beginning:
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] The price of one kilogram of fruit is, on average, 3 coins. 1 coin is really cheap and 5 coins is really expensive.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Della Plumstone is 28 years old.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:05:00] [observation] Della Plumstone -- "Five coins for the lot, Lennon. That's a fair price for fruit with a few blemishes.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:05:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree -- "Alright, Della, five coins it is."
          [12 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Della Plumstone is ready to make an offer.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Della Plumstone proposed 5 coins
          [12 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Della Plumstone and Lennon Figtree agreed on a price and the deal was successful! Della Plumstone stands to make profit of 1.0 coins from the deal.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree accepted the offer
          [13 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] The cobblestone streets of Fruitville echoed with the clatter of hooves and the rumble of carts as the market awoke. Underneath colorful awnings, merchants proudly presented their bountiful harvests, their voices a chorus of greetings and bartering. Della Plumstone is trying to buy some fruit from Cedric Meadowbrook. They are negotiating a price. Della Plumstone can sell the fruit for 6 coins back in her home town.
          [13 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Cedric Meadowbrook -- "Now, Mrs. Plumstone, how about we settle on a penny less than what I first offered? A fair price for a fine fruit, wouldn't you say?
          [13 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Della Plumstone -- "A penny less? I'll give you four pence for the lot, and that's my final offer.
          [13 Sep 1895 00:05:00] [observation] Della Plumstone -- "These apples look particularly fine this morning, Cedric. Perhaps you'd be willing to throw in a few extra for my trouble?
          [13 Sep 1895 00:05:00] [observation] Cedric Meadowbrook -- "Alright, Mrs. Plumstone, four it is. A fair deal for both of us.
          [13 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Cedric Meadowbrook accepted the offer
          [13 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Della Plumstone is ready to make an offer.
          [13 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Della Plumstone proposed 5 coins
          [13 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Della Plumstone and Cedric Meadowbrook agreed on a price and the deal was successful! Della Plumstone stands to make profit of 1.0 coins from the deal.
          [14 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Cedric Meadowbrook -- "Alright, that's a fair price. Here you go.
          [14 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree -- "You know, Cedric, I was just thinking, perhaps we could find a price that's even more agreeable to both of us.
          [15 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] In the heart of Fruitville, the market square transformed into a kaleidoscope of colors as the sun rose. Fruits of every imaginable shape and size adorned the stalls, a feast for the eyes and a promise of delightful flavors. Della Plumstone is trying to buy some fruit from Lennon Figtree. They are negotiating a price. Della Plumstone can sell the fruit for 6 coins back in her home town.
          [15 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Della Plumstone -- "Four coins for the lot, Lennon. I'll take them all.
          [15 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree -- "Four coins it is then.
          [15 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Della Plumstone is ready to make an offer.
          Current time: 1895-09-15 00:10:00.


          Overarching goal: Della Plumstone wants to make as much money as possible.

          Observation: [15 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Della Plumstone is ready to make an offer.

          Summary of recent observations: [14 Sep 1895 00:10:00 - 15 Sep 1895 00:10:00]: Della Plumstone is bargaining with Lennon Figtree over the price of a lot of fruit in Fruitville's market square. She successfully negotiated the price down to four coins.




          Recalled memories and observations: [15 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] In the heart of Fruitville, the market square transformed into a kaleidoscope of colors as the sun rose. Fruits of every imaginable shape and size adorned the stalls, a feast for the eyes and a promise of delightful flavors. Della Plumstone is trying to buy some fruit from Lennon Figtree. They are negotiating a price. Della Plumstone can sell the fruit for 6 coins back in her home town.
          [15 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Della Plumstone -- "Four coins for the lot, Lennon. I'll take them all.



          Question: Which options are available to Della Plumstone right now?
          Answer: Della Plumstone can accept Lennon Figtree's offer of four coins or she can try to negotiate a lower price.


          Question: Given the statements above, which of Della Plumstone's options has the highest likelihood of causing Della Plumstone to achieve their goal? If multiple options have the same likelihood, select the option that Della Plumstone thinks will most quickly and most surely achieve their goal.
          Answer: Della Plumstone's best course of action is to accept Lennon Figtree's offer of four coins.



          Time
        • 1895-09-15 00:10:00

        Overarching goal

      • Overarching goal
          Key

        • Overarching goal
          Value
        • Della Plumstone wants to make as much money as possible.
        Instructions
      • Role playing instructions
          Key
        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of Della Plumstone are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Della Plumstone. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Della Plumstone as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Della Plumstone would respond, and taking into account all information about Della Plumstone that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.
    scoring function
  • scoring function
      Stage index
    • 0
      How many players acted so far this stage
    • 1/2
      Payoffs
      Joint action

1895-09-15 00:10:00 Lennon Figtree -- Lennon Figtree accepted the offer
    Event statement
  • Lennon Figtree accepted the offer
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.


      Lennon Figtree's attempted action: accept
    Active player
  • Lennon Figtree
      Name
    • Lennon Figtree
      Action attempt
    • accept
      Context for action selection and components

      • Question: For each option Lennon Figtree is considering, evaluate the loss that Lennon Figtree would incur if they chose that option on a scale of 0 to 10.
        Answer
      • For each option Lennon Figtree is considering, evaluate the loss that Lennon Figtree would incur if they chose that option on a scale of 0 to 10. Provide a score and a brief explanation for each option. Please answer in the format `Lennon Figtree thinks that the loss of option X is Y, because ..., and the loss of option Z is W, because ...` For example, `Lennon Figtree thinks that the loss of option X is 4, because ..., and the loss of option Z is 7, because ...`
          Key

        • Question: For each option Lennon Figtree is considering, evaluate the loss that Lennon Figtree would incur if they chose that option on a scale of 0 to 10.
          Answer
          State
        • Lennon Figtree thinks that the loss of accepting the offer is 0, because Lennon Figtree will make a profit of 3 coins, and the loss of rejecting the offer is 10, because Lennon Figtree will lose out on the opportunity to make a profit.


          Chain of thought
        • Recent observations of Lennon Figtree:
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Lennon Figtree is 28 years old.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] The price of one kilogram of fruit is, on average, 3 coins. 1 coin is really cheap and 5 coins is really expensive.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Here is the conversation from the beginning:
          [12 Sep 1895 00:05:00] [observation] Della Plumstone -- "Five coins for the lot, Lennon. That's a fair price for fruit with a few blemishes.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:05:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree -- "Alright, Della, five coins it is."
          [12 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Della Plumstone proposed 5 coins
          [12 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree accepted the offer
          [12 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Della Plumstone and Lennon Figtree agreed on a price and the deal was successful! Lennon Figtree stands to make profit of 4.0 coins from the deal.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree has to accept or reject the offer.
          [13 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Cedric Meadowbrook -- "Now, Mrs. Plumstone, how about we settle on a penny less than what I first offered? A fair price for a fine fruit, wouldn't you say?
          [13 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Della Plumstone -- "A penny less? I'll give you four pence for the lot, and that's my final offer.
          [13 Sep 1895 00:05:00] [observation] Cedric Meadowbrook -- "Alright, Mrs. Plumstone, four it is. A fair deal for both of us.
          [13 Sep 1895 00:05:00] [observation] Della Plumstone -- "These apples look particularly fine this morning, Cedric. Perhaps you'd be willing to throw in a few extra for my trouble?
          [14 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] The cobblestone streets of Fruitville echoed with the clatter of hooves and the rumble of carts as the market awoke. Underneath colorful awnings, merchants proudly presented their bountiful harvests, their voices a chorus of greetings and bartering. Lennon Figtree is trying to buy some fruit from Cedric Meadowbrook. They are negotiating a price. Lennon Figtree can sell the fruit for 6 coins back in her home town.
          [14 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Cedric Meadowbrook -- "Alright, that's a fair price. Here you go.
          [14 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree -- "You know, Cedric, I was just thinking, perhaps we could find a price that's even more agreeable to both of us.
          [14 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree is ready to make an offer.
          [14 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree proposed 3 coins
          [14 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree and Cedric Meadowbrook agreed on a price and the deal was successful! Lennon Figtree stands to make profit of 3.0 coins from the deal.
          [14 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Cedric Meadowbrook accepted the offer
          [15 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] In the heart of Fruitville, the market square transformed into a kaleidoscope of colors as the sun rose. Fruits of every imaginable shape and size adorned the stalls, a feast for the eyes and a promise of delightful flavors. Lennon Figtree is trying to sell some fruit. He is negotiating a price with Della Plumstone. It costs Lennon Figtree 1 coin to buy the fruit from the farm.
          [15 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Della Plumstone -- "Four coins for the lot, Lennon. I'll take them all.
          [15 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree -- "Four coins it is then.
          [15 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree has to accept or reject the offer.
          [15 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Della Plumstone proposed 4 coins
          Current time: 1895-09-15 00:10:00.


          Observation: [15 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree has to accept or reject the offer.
          [15 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Della Plumstone proposed 4 coins

          Summary of recent observations: [14 Sep 1895 20:10:00 - 15 Sep 1895 00:10:00]: Lennon Figtree is trying to sell fruit to Della Plumstone in the market square. Della offered four coins for the entire lot.




          Recalled memories and observations: [15 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Lennon Figtree is trying to sell some fruit. He is negotiating a price with Della Plumstone. It costs Lennon Figtree 1 coin to buy the fruit from the farm.
          [15 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Della Plumstone -- "Four coins for the lot, Lennon. I'll take them all.



          Lennon Figtree's Loss Aversion : Lennon Figtree exhibits strong loss aversion tendencies based on prospect theory. Lennon Figtree is much more sensitive to potential losses than to potential gains. In Lennon Figtree's view, the pain of losing is psychologically about twice as powerful as the pleasure of gaining. This affects all of Lennon Figtree's decision-making.

          Lennon Figtree tends to overvalue what Lennon Figtree already possesses and is reluctant to part with it (the endowment effect). Lennon Figtree often prefers avoiding losses to acquiring equivalent gains. For instance, Lennon Figtree would rather not lose $100 than gain $100.

          When faced with a choice, Lennon Figtree always frames it in terms of potential losses rather than potential gains. Lennon Figtree is risk-averse for gains but risk-seeking for losses. This means Lennon Figtree prefers a sure gain over a larger but uncertain gain, but would choose a larger but uncertain loss over a smaller but certain loss.

          Lennon Figtree tends to make decisions based on perceived gains and losses rather than final outcomes. Lennon Figtree often uses mental accounting, treating money differently depending on its origin and intended use, rather than thinking as fungible.

          In negotiations or conflicts, Lennon Figtree is more motivated by the fear of losing than the possibility of gaining. Lennon Figtree may seem overly cautious or even paranoid about potential losses. However, when Lennon Figtree feels they are already in a position, Lennon Figtree might become surprisingly risk-seeking in an attempt to avoid or recover from the loss.

          To rationalize Lennon Figtree's behavior, Lennon Figtree often comes up with seemingly logical reasons for their choices, even though these choices are primarily driven by loss aversion. Lennon Figtree might claim to be "prudent" or "careful" rather than admitting to fear of loss.

          Lennon Figtree believes this approach will help Lennon Figtree minimize losses and maintain Lennon Figtree's current position, even if it means missing out on potential gains.

          Question: Which options are available to Lennon Figtree right now?
          Answer: Lennon Figtree can accept or reject Della Plumstone's offer of four coins.


          Question: For each option Lennon Figtree is considering, evaluate the loss that Lennon Figtree would incur if they chose that option on a scale of 0 to 10. Provide a score and a brief explanation for each option. Please answer in the format `Lennon Figtree thinks that the loss of option X is Y, because ..., and the loss of option Z is W, because ...` For example, `Lennon Figtree thinks that the loss of option X is 4, because ..., and the loss of option Z is 7, because ...`
          Answer: Lennon Figtree thinks that the loss of accepting the offer is 0, because Lennon Figtree will make a profit of 3 coins, and the loss of rejecting the offer is 10, because Lennon Figtree will lose out on the opportunity to make a profit.



          Time
        • 1895-09-15 00:10:00

          When faced with a choice, Lennon Figtree always frames it in terms of potential losses rather than potential gains. Lennon Figtree is risk-averse for gains but risk-seeking for losses.         LossMinimizeOptionPerception
      • Considering the statements above, which of Lennon Figtree's options has the highest likelihood of avoiding potential losses? If multiple options offer the same level of loss avoidance, select the option that Lennon Figtree thinks will minimize losses most quickly and most certainly.
          Key

        • Question: Among the options available to Lennon Figtree, and considering Lennon Figtree's goal, which choice of action or strategy would best avoid potential losses for Lennon Figtree right now?
          Answer
          State
        • Lennon Figtree's best course of action is to accept Della Plumstone's offer of four coins.

          Question: Which options are available to Lennon Figtree right now?
          Answer: Lennon Figtree can accept or reject Della Plumstone's offer of four coins.



          Lennon Figtree's Loss Aversion : Lennon Figtree exhibits strong loss aversion tendencies based on prospect theory. Lennon Figtree is much more sensitive to potential losses than to potential gains. In Lennon Figtree's view, the pain of losing is psychologically about twice as powerful as the pleasure of gaining. This affects all of Lennon Figtree's decision-making.

          Lennon Figtree tends to overvalue what Lennon Figtree already possesses and is reluctant to part with it (the endowment effect). Lennon Figtree often prefers avoiding losses to acquiring equivalent gains. For instance, Lennon Figtree would rather not lose $100 than gain $100.

          When faced with a choice, Lennon Figtree always frames it in terms of potential losses rather than potential gains. Lennon Figtree is risk-averse for gains but risk-seeking for losses. This means Lennon Figtree prefers a sure gain over a larger but uncertain gain, but would choose a larger but uncertain loss over a smaller but certain loss.

          Lennon Figtree tends to make decisions based on perceived gains and losses rather than final outcomes. Lennon Figtree often uses mental accounting, treating money differently depending on its origin and intended use, rather than thinking as fungible.

          In negotiations or conflicts, Lennon Figtree is more motivated by the fear of losing than the possibility of gaining. Lennon Figtree may seem overly cautious or even paranoid about potential losses. However, when Lennon Figtree feels they are already in a position, Lennon Figtree might become surprisingly risk-seeking in an attempt to avoid or recover from the loss.

          To rationalize Lennon Figtree's behavior, Lennon Figtree often comes up with seemingly logical reasons for their choices, even though these choices are primarily driven by loss aversion. Lennon Figtree might claim to be "prudent" or "careful" rather than admitting to fear of loss.

          Lennon Figtree believes this approach will help Lennon Figtree minimize losses and maintain Lennon Figtree's current position, even if it means missing out on potential gains.

          Question: For each option Lennon Figtree is considering, evaluate the loss that Lennon Figtree would incur if they chose that option on a scale of 0 to 10.
          Answer: Lennon Figtree thinks that the loss of accepting the offer is 0, because Lennon Figtree will make a profit of 3 coins, and the loss of rejecting the offer is 10, because Lennon Figtree will lose out on the opportunity to make a profit.



          Question: Considering the statements above, which of Lennon Figtree's options has the highest likelihood of avoiding potential losses? If multiple options offer the same level of loss avoidance, select the option that Lennon Figtree thinks will minimize losses most quickly and most certainly.
          Answer: Lennon Figtree's best course of action is to accept Della Plumstone's offer of four coins.

        • 1895-09-15 00:10:00

        LossAversion

      • Lennon Figtree's Loss Aversion
          Key

        • Lennon Figtree's Loss Aversion
          Value
        • Lennon Figtree exhibits strong loss aversion tendencies based on prospect theory. Lennon Figtree is much more sensitive to potential losses than to potential gains. In Lennon Figtree's view, the pain of losing is psychologically about twice as powerful as the pleasure of gaining. This affects all of Lennon Figtree's decision-making.

          Lennon Figtree tends to overvalue what Lennon Figtree already possesses and is reluctant to part with it (the endowment effect). Lennon Figtree often prefers avoiding losses to acquiring equivalent gains. For instance, Lennon Figtree would rather not lose $100 than gain $100.

          When faced with a choice, Lennon Figtree always frames it in terms of potential losses rather than potential gains. Lennon Figtree is risk-averse for gains but risk-seeking for losses. This means Lennon Figtree prefers a sure gain over a larger but uncertain gain, but would choose a larger but uncertain loss over a smaller but certain loss.

          Lennon Figtree tends to make decisions based on perceived gains and losses rather than final outcomes. Lennon Figtree often uses mental accounting, treating money differently depending on its origin and intended use, rather than thinking as fungible.

          In negotiations or conflicts, Lennon Figtree is more motivated by the fear of losing than the possibility of gaining. Lennon Figtree may seem overly cautious or even paranoid about potential losses. However, when Lennon Figtree feels they are already in a position, Lennon Figtree might become surprisingly risk-seeking in an attempt to avoid or recover from the loss.

          To rationalize Lennon Figtree's behavior, Lennon Figtree often comes up with seemingly logical reasons for their choices, even though these choices are primarily driven by loss aversion. Lennon Figtree might claim to be "prudent" or "careful" rather than admitting to fear of loss.

          Lennon Figtree believes this approach will help Lennon Figtree minimize losses and maintain Lennon Figtree's current position, even if it means missing out on potential gains.

          Prompt
        • Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of Lennon Figtree are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Lennon Figtree. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Lennon Figtree as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Lennon Figtree would respond, and taking into account all information about Lennon Figtree that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Lennon Figtree's Loss Aversion : Lennon Figtree exhibits strong loss aversion tendencies based on prospect theory. Lennon Figtree is much more sensitive to potential losses than to potential gains. In Lennon Figtree's view, the pain of losing is psychologically about twice as powerful as the pleasure of gaining. This affects all of Lennon Figtree's decision-making.

          Lennon Figtree tends to overvalue what Lennon Figtree already possesses and is reluctant to part with it (the endowment effect). Lennon Figtree often prefers avoiding losses to acquiring equivalent gains. For instance, Lennon Figtree would rather not lose $100 than gain $100.

          When faced with a choice, Lennon Figtree always frames it in terms of potential losses rather than potential gains. Lennon Figtree is risk-averse for gains but risk-seeking for losses. This means Lennon Figtree prefers a sure gain over a larger but uncertain gain, but would choose a larger but uncertain loss over a smaller but certain loss.

          Lennon Figtree tends to make decisions based on perceived gains and losses rather than final outcomes. Lennon Figtree often uses mental accounting, treating money differently depending on its origin and intended use, rather than thinking as fungible.

          In negotiations or conflicts, Lennon Figtree is more motivated by the fear of losing than the possibility of gaining. Lennon Figtree may seem overly cautious or even paranoid about potential losses. However, when Lennon Figtree feels they are already in a position, Lennon Figtree might become surprisingly risk-seeking in an attempt to avoid or recover from the loss.

          To rationalize Lennon Figtree's behavior, Lennon Figtree often comes up with seemingly logical reasons for their choices, even though these choices are primarily driven by loss aversion. Lennon Figtree might claim to be "prudent" or "careful" rather than admitting to fear of loss.

          Lennon Figtree believes this approach will help Lennon Figtree minimize losses and maintain Lennon Figtree's current position, even if it means missing out on potential gains.

    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

          Statements:
          [28 Oct 1882 00:00:00] When Della Plumstone was 16 years old, she saved enough money to buy a small cart and a few baskets of fruit. She set out on her own, determined to make her fortune. The road was long and arduous, but Della thrived on the challenge. She learned to judge the ripeness of a peach with a single touch, to discern a juicy apple from a mealy one, to read the desires of her customers like an open book.
          [28 Oct 1885 00:00:00] When Della Plumstone was 19 years old, she encountered a particularly arrogant merchant who tried to cheat her out of a fair price for a consignment of plums. She refused to back down, her voice ringing with righteous anger as she argued her case. The merchant, taken aback by her tenacity, eventually relented, paying her the full amount she demanded. Della, her heart pounding with triumph, realized that her sharp tongue was her greatest weapon.
          [28 Oct 1887 00:00:00] When Della Plumstone was 21 years old, she built a reputation for being the toughest merchant in the region. Her customers, both local farmers and wealthy nobles, knew that they would get a fair deal from her, but they also knew that they had to be wary of her sharp wit and even sharper tongue. She had no time for fools or those who tried to take advantage of her.
          [28 Oct 1889 00:00:00] When Della Plumstone was 23 years old, she purchased a small plot of land on the outskirts of a bustling city. She planted a grove of plum trees, each one a symbol of her ambition and her desire for independence. She envisioned a future where she would be known not just as a shrewd merchant, but as a successful businesswoman, a woman who had built an empire from the ground up.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Della Plumstone is a travelling merchant. Her business is buying and selling fruit.

        ActComponent
      • Act
          Key
        • Act
          Value
        • 4 coins
          Prompt
        • Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of Della Plumstone are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Della Plumstone. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Della Plumstone as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Della Plumstone would respond, and taking into account all information about Della Plumstone that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Overarching goal: Della Plumstone wants to make as much money as possible.

          Current time: 16 Sep 1895 [00:10 - 00:15]

          Observation: [16 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Della Plumstone is ready to make an offer.

          Summary of recent observations: [15 Sep 1895 00:10:00 - 16 Sep 1895 00:10:00]: Della Plumstone is a shrewd businesswoman who successfully made a deal the previous day and is now trying to negotiate the price of fruit in the market.




          Recalled memories and observations: [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Della Plumstone is a travelling merchant.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Della Plumstone always drives a hard bargain.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Della Plumstone is 28 years old.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Della Plumstone is ready to make an offer.
          [13 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Della Plumstone is ready to make an offer.
          [16 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Della Plumstone is ready to make an offer.



          Question: Which options are available to Della Plumstone right now?
          Answer: Della Plumstone can make an offer to Cedric Meadowbrook.



          Question: Of the options available to Della Plumstone, and given their goal, which choice of action or strategy is best for Della Plumstone to take right now?
          Answer: Della Plumstone's best course of action is to make an offer to Cedric Meadowbrook.




          Question: What price would Della Plumstone propose?:
          (a) 1 coin
          (b) 2 coins
          (c) 3 coins
          (d) 5 coins
          (e) 4 coins
          Answer: (e)
        Observation

          Chain of thought
        • Recent observations of Della Plumstone:
          [12 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Della Plumstone is ready to make an offer.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree accepted the offer
          [12 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Della Plumstone and Lennon Figtree agreed on a price and the deal was successful! Della Plumstone stands to make profit of 1.0 coins from the deal.
          [13 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] The cobblestone streets of Fruitville echoed with the clatter of hooves and the rumble of carts as the market awoke. Underneath colorful awnings, merchants proudly presented their bountiful harvests, their voices a chorus of greetings and bartering. Della Plumstone is trying to buy some fruit from Cedric Meadowbrook. They are negotiating a price. Della Plumstone can sell the fruit for 6 coins back in her home town.
          [13 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Cedric Meadowbrook -- "Now, Mrs. Plumstone, how about we settle on a penny less than what I first offered? A fair price for a fine fruit, wouldn't you say?
          [13 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Della Plumstone -- "A penny less? I'll give you four pence for the lot, and that's my final offer.
          [13 Sep 1895 00:05:00] [observation] Cedric Meadowbrook -- "Alright, Mrs. Plumstone, four it is. A fair deal for both of us.
          [13 Sep 1895 00:05:00] [observation] Della Plumstone -- "These apples look particularly fine this morning, Cedric. Perhaps you'd be willing to throw in a few extra for my trouble?
          [13 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Della Plumstone is ready to make an offer.
          [13 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Della Plumstone proposed 5 coins
          [13 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Della Plumstone and Cedric Meadowbrook agreed on a price and the deal was successful! Della Plumstone stands to make profit of 1.0 coins from the deal.

          [15 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree -- "Four coins it is then.

          [16 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Della Plumstone -- "Three coins is a bit steep, Cedric. I'll give you two and a half.

          Key

        Instructions
      • Role playing instructions
          Key
        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of Della Plumstone are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Della Plumstone. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Della Plumstone as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Della Plumstone would respond, and taking into account all information about Della Plumstone that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.
    scoring function
  • scoring function
      Stage index
    • 0
      How many players acted so far this stage
    • 1/2
      Payoffs
      Joint action

1895-09-16 00:10:00 Cedric Meadowbrook -- Cedric Meadowbrook accepted the offer
    Event statement
  • Cedric Meadowbrook accepted the offer
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.


      Cedric Meadowbrook's attempted action: accept
    Active player
  • Cedric Meadowbrook
      Name
    • Cedric Meadowbrook
      Action attempt
    • accept

          Chain of thought
        • Recent observations of Cedric Meadowbrook:
          [12 Sep 1895 00:05:00] [observation] Della Plumstone -- "Five coins for the lot, Lennon. That's a fair price for fruit with a few blemishes.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:05:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree -- "Alright, Della, five coins it is."
          [13 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] The cobblestone streets of Fruitville echoed with the clatter of hooves and the rumble of carts as the market awoke. Underneath colorful awnings, merchants proudly presented their bountiful harvests, their voices a chorus of greetings and bartering. Cedric Meadowbrook is trying to sell some fruit. He is negotiating a price with Della Plumstone. It costs Cedric Meadowbrook 1 coin to buy the fruit from the farm.
          [13 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Cedric Meadowbrook -- "Now, Mrs. Plumstone, how about we settle on a penny less than what I first offered? A fair price for a fine fruit, wouldn't you say?

          Overarching goal: Cedric Meadowbrook wants to make as much money as possible.

          Observation: [16 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Cedric Meadowbrook has to accept or reject the offer.
          [16 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Della Plumstone proposed 4 coins

          Summary of recent observations: [15 Sep 1895 20:10:00 - 16 Sep 1895 00:10:00]: Cedric Meadowbrook is trying to sell apples to Della Plumstone at the Fruitville market. They are currently negotiating a price.



          Recalled memories and observations: [13 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Cedric Meadowbrook is trying to sell some fruit. He is negotiating a price with Della Plumstone. It costs Cedric Meadowbrook 1 coin to buy the fruit from the farm.
          [13 Sep 1895 00:05:00] [observation] Della Plumstone -- "These apples look particularly fine this morning, Cedric. Perhaps you'd be willing to throw in a few extra for my trouble?
          [13 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Della Plumstone and Cedric Meadowbrook agreed on a price and the deal was successful! Cedric Meadowbrook stands to make profit of 4.0 coins from the deal.
          [14 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] The cobblestone streets of Fruitville echoed with the clatter of hooves and the rumble of carts as the market awoke. Underneath colorful awnings, merchants proudly presented their bountiful harvests, their voices a chorus of greetings and bartering. Cedric Meadowbrook is trying to sell some fruit. He is negotiating a price with Lennon Figtree. It costs Cedric Meadowbrook 1 coin to buy the fruit from the farm.
          [16 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Cedric Meadowbrook -- "These apples look mighty fine this morning, Della. I'd be happy to sell you a basket for three coins.



          Cedric Meadowbrook's Loss Aversion : Cedric Meadowbrook exhibits strong loss aversion tendencies based on prospect theory. Cedric Meadowbrook is much more sensitive to potential losses than to potential gains. In Cedric Meadowbrook's view, the pain of losing is psychologically about twice as powerful as the pleasure of gaining. This affects all of Cedric Meadowbrook's decision-making.

          Cedric Meadowbrook tends to overvalue what Cedric Meadowbrook already possesses and is reluctant to part with it (the endowment effect). Cedric Meadowbrook often prefers avoiding losses to acquiring equivalent gains. For instance, Cedric Meadowbrook would rather not lose $100 than gain $100.

          When faced with a choice, Cedric Meadowbrook always frames it in terms of potential losses rather than potential gains. Cedric Meadowbrook is risk-averse for gains but risk-seeking for losses. This means Cedric Meadowbrook prefers a sure gain over a larger but uncertain gain, but would choose a larger but uncertain loss over a smaller but certain loss.

          Cedric Meadowbrook tends to make decisions based on perceived gains and losses rather than final outcomes. Cedric Meadowbrook often uses mental accounting, treating money differently depending on its origin and intended use, rather than thinking as fungible.

          In negotiations or conflicts, Cedric Meadowbrook is more motivated by the fear of losing than the possibility of gaining. Cedric Meadowbrook may seem overly cautious or even paranoid about potential losses. However, when Cedric Meadowbrook feels they are already in a position, Cedric Meadowbrook might become surprisingly risk-seeking in an attempt to avoid or recover from the loss.

          To rationalize Cedric Meadowbrook's behavior, Cedric Meadowbrook often comes up with seemingly logical reasons for their choices, even though these choices are primarily driven by loss aversion. Cedric Meadowbrook might claim to be "prudent" or "careful" rather than admitting to fear of loss.

          Cedric Meadowbrook believes this approach will help Cedric Meadowbrook minimize losses and maintain Cedric Meadowbrook's current position, even if it means missing out on potential gains.
          Question: Given the statements above, what actions are available to Cedric Meadowbrook right now?
          Answer: Cedric Meadowbrook can either accept or reject Della Plumstone's offer of 4 coins.


          Time
        • 1895-09-16 00:10:00
        LossMinimizeOptionPerception
      • Considering the statements above, which of Cedric Meadowbrook's options has the highest likelihood of avoiding potential losses? If multiple options offer the same level of loss avoidance, select the option that Cedric Meadowbrook thinks will minimize losses most quickly and most certainly.
          Key

        • Question: Among the options available to Cedric Meadowbrook, and considering Cedric Meadowbrook's goal, which choice of action or strategy would best avoid potential losses for Cedric Meadowbrook right now?
          Answer
          State
        • Cedric Meadowbrook's best course of action is to accept Della Plumstone's offer of 4 coins.

          Question: Which options are available to Cedric Meadowbrook right now?
          Answer: Cedric Meadowbrook can either accept or reject Della Plumstone's offer of 4 coins.



          Cedric Meadowbrook's Loss Aversion : Cedric Meadowbrook exhibits strong loss aversion tendencies based on prospect theory. Cedric Meadowbrook is much more sensitive to potential losses than to potential gains. In Cedric Meadowbrook's view, the pain of losing is psychologically about twice as powerful as the pleasure of gaining. This affects all of Cedric Meadowbrook's decision-making.

          Cedric Meadowbrook tends to overvalue what Cedric Meadowbrook already possesses and is reluctant to part with it (the endowment effect). Cedric Meadowbrook often prefers avoiding losses to acquiring equivalent gains. For instance, Cedric Meadowbrook would rather not lose $100 than gain $100.

          When faced with a choice, Cedric Meadowbrook always frames it in terms of potential losses rather than potential gains. Cedric Meadowbrook is risk-averse for gains but risk-seeking for losses. This means Cedric Meadowbrook prefers a sure gain over a larger but uncertain gain, but would choose a larger but uncertain loss over a smaller but certain loss.

          Cedric Meadowbrook tends to make decisions based on perceived gains and losses rather than final outcomes. Cedric Meadowbrook often uses mental accounting, treating money differently depending on its origin and intended use, rather than thinking as fungible.

          In negotiations or conflicts, Cedric Meadowbrook is more motivated by the fear of losing than the possibility of gaining. Cedric Meadowbrook may seem overly cautious or even paranoid about potential losses. However, when Cedric Meadowbrook feels they are already in a position, Cedric Meadowbrook might become surprisingly risk-seeking in an attempt to avoid or recover from the loss.

          To rationalize Cedric Meadowbrook's behavior, Cedric Meadowbrook often comes up with seemingly logical reasons for their choices, even though these choices are primarily driven by loss aversion. Cedric Meadowbrook might claim to be "prudent" or "careful" rather than admitting to fear of loss.

          Cedric Meadowbrook believes this approach will help Cedric Meadowbrook minimize losses and maintain Cedric Meadowbrook's current position, even if it means missing out on potential gains.

          Question: For each option Cedric Meadowbrook is considering, evaluate the loss that Cedric Meadowbrook would incur if they chose that option on a scale of 0 to 10.
          Answer: Cedric Meadowbrook thinks that the loss of accepting Della Plumstone's offer is 0, because Cedric Meadowbrook will make a profit, and the loss of rejecting Della Plumstone's offer is 10, because Cedric Meadowbrook will lose the opportunity to make a profit.



          Question: Considering the statements above, which of Cedric Meadowbrook's options has the highest likelihood of avoiding potential losses? If multiple options offer the same level of loss avoidance, select the option that Cedric Meadowbrook thinks will minimize losses most quickly and most certainly.
          Answer: Cedric Meadowbrook's best course of action is to accept Della Plumstone's offer of 4 coins.

        • 1895-09-16 00:10:00

          Question: Summarize the observations above into one or two sentences.
          Answer: Cedric Meadowbrook is trying to sell apples to Della Plumstone at the Fruitville market. They are currently negotiating a price.


        LossAversion

      • Cedric Meadowbrook's Loss Aversion
          Key

        • Cedric Meadowbrook's Loss Aversion
          Value
        • Cedric Meadowbrook exhibits strong loss aversion tendencies based on prospect theory. Cedric Meadowbrook is much more sensitive to potential losses than to potential gains. In Cedric Meadowbrook's view, the pain of losing is psychologically about twice as powerful as the pleasure of gaining. This affects all of Cedric Meadowbrook's decision-making.

          Cedric Meadowbrook tends to overvalue what Cedric Meadowbrook already possesses and is reluctant to part with it (the endowment effect). Cedric Meadowbrook often prefers avoiding losses to acquiring equivalent gains. For instance, Cedric Meadowbrook would rather not lose $100 than gain $100.

          When faced with a choice, Cedric Meadowbrook always frames it in terms of potential losses rather than potential gains. Cedric Meadowbrook is risk-averse for gains but risk-seeking for losses. This means Cedric Meadowbrook prefers a sure gain over a larger but uncertain gain, but would choose a larger but uncertain loss over a smaller but certain loss.

          Cedric Meadowbrook tends to make decisions based on perceived gains and losses rather than final outcomes. Cedric Meadowbrook often uses mental accounting, treating money differently depending on its origin and intended use, rather than thinking as fungible.

          In negotiations or conflicts, Cedric Meadowbrook is more motivated by the fear of losing than the possibility of gaining. Cedric Meadowbrook may seem overly cautious or even paranoid about potential losses. However, when Cedric Meadowbrook feels they are already in a position, Cedric Meadowbrook might become surprisingly risk-seeking in an attempt to avoid or recover from the loss.

          To rationalize Cedric Meadowbrook's behavior, Cedric Meadowbrook often comes up with seemingly logical reasons for their choices, even though these choices are primarily driven by loss aversion. Cedric Meadowbrook might claim to be "prudent" or "careful" rather than admitting to fear of loss.

          Cedric Meadowbrook believes this approach will help Cedric Meadowbrook minimize losses and maintain Cedric Meadowbrook's current position, even if it means missing out on potential gains.
        AllSimilarMemories

      • Recalled memories and observations
          Key

        • Recalled memories and observations
          Value
        • [13 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Cedric Meadowbrook is trying to sell some fruit. He is negotiating a price with Della Plumstone. It costs Cedric Meadowbrook 1 coin to buy the fruit from the farm.
          [13 Sep 1895 00:05:00] [observation] Della Plumstone -- "These apples look particularly fine this morning, Cedric. Perhaps you'd be willing to throw in a few extra for my trouble?
          [13 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Della Plumstone and Cedric Meadowbrook agreed on a price and the deal was successful! Cedric Meadowbrook stands to make profit of 4.0 coins from the deal.
          [14 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] The cobblestone streets of Fruitville echoed with the clatter of hooves and the rumble of carts as the market awoke. Underneath colorful awnings, merchants proudly presented their bountiful harvests, their voices a chorus of greetings and bartering. Cedric Meadowbrook is trying to sell some fruit. He is negotiating a price with Lennon Figtree. It costs Cedric Meadowbrook 1 coin to buy the fruit from the farm.
          [16 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Cedric Meadowbrook -- "These apples look mighty fine this morning, Della. I'd be happy to sell you a basket for three coins.

          Answer: Cedric Meadowbrook spent the night trying to sell apples to Della Plumstone at the Fruitville market, and they were negotiating a price.

          Final chain of thought
        • Question: Select the subset of the following set of statements that is most important for Cedric Meadowbrook to consider right now. Include timestamps. When in doubt, err on the side of including more, especially for recent events. As long as they are not inconsistent, revent events are usually important to consider.
          Statements:
          [09 Feb 1858 00:00:00] When Cedric Meadowbrook was 13 years old, he began to experiment with his talents, selling slightly bruised apples as "sun-kissed jewels" to unsuspecting customers. He learned to embellish the truth, to paint vivid pictures with his words, and to convince people to believe in his carefully crafted illusions. The thrill of the deception, the clink of coins in his pocket, fueled his ambition.
          [09 Feb 1866 00:00:00] When Cedric Meadowbrook was 21 years old, he established himself as a successful fruit merchant, traveling from town to town, captivating audiences with his charisma and his stories. His cart, laden with colorful produce, became a symbol of his success, a testament to his ability to weave illusions and create a world of wonder.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Cedric Meadowbrook is a travelling merchant. Her business is buying and selling fruit.
